column2: New State and local government bonds aggregating $30,296,000 were sold yesterday to dealers.

LONDON, Dec. 18--Sir E. Farquhar Buzzard, medical attendant to three Kings, George V. Edward VIII and George VI, died today in an Oxford hospital. He was within two days of his seventy-fourth birthday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--Captain Charles B. McVay 3d testified today that he did not have the cruiser Indianapolis follow a zigzag course on the night she was sunk because the moon was obscured by clouds and the visibility was bad.

The assessed valuations of the Hotel St. Regis, southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, have been ordered reduced $1,450,000, from $11,800,000 to $10,350,000 for the three tax years...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18-- New securities offered for cash in amounts exceeding $100,000 totaled $1,452,000,000 in September, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today in its monthly statistical bulletin.

A record-breaking year for advertising and marketing in 1946 was forecast yesterday in a survey made among advertising magazines affiliated with the National Conference of Business Papers. Greater efforts than ever before will be expended on selling goods, the report disclosed.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 18--In the present fiscal year, which ends Dec. 31, the Argentine Government will have dedicated slightly more than one-half of its total expenditure and more than all of its revenue to military purposes, according to budget estimates made public late last night.

MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 19-- Masaharu Homma, who as a lieutenant general of the Japanese Army conquered Bataan and Corregidor in 1942, pleaded not guilty to war criminal charges when he was arraigned before a United...
CHICAGO, Dec. 18--The Department of Agriculture's final estimate of the 1945 grain crops, made late today, showed a moderate reduction compared with the preliminary returns, but the de-...
HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP)--Threats of a "silent strike" by horsemen at Gulfstream Park dissipated today with announcement of $2,000 minimum purses and additional trainers' awards.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Phelps Stokes of Washington, D. C., and Pearl Island, Upper St. Regis, N. Y., have announced here the engagement of their eldest daughter, Helen Elizabeth, to Robert Bradshaw Hawkins of Bombay, India, and Claremont, Calif., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Jeans Hawkins of Claremont.

New York will retain its dominant position as the pre-eminent apparel manufacturing city of the nation in the transition period and beyond, Louis Rubin, executive chairman of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group, Inc., declared last night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 18 --First-degree murder charges against two women in unrelated homicide cases were disposed of today before County Judge Frederick G. Schmidt when one defendant was permitted to plead guilty to second-degree murder and the other won a dismissal of her indictment on the ground she had bean temporarily insane.

A middle-aged couple, their daughter and her infant son have been caught in the middle of a dispute between a landlord and the Office of Price Administration, it developed yesterday, after a hearing in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--President Truman bestowed the Congressional Medal of Honor on six heroes of the Army, the Navy and the Marine Corps today before members of their immediate families and heads of the service branches gathered in his office.

Expressing sympathy with the predicament of the Green Bus Lines in Queens, Supreme Court Justice Percy D. Stoddart denied yesterday a petition of the company for a temporary restraining order against a drivers' and maintenance workers' strike which has interfered with bus service on thirteen routes in southern Queens and the Rockaways.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--The acute shortage of cotton house dresses and other low-cost cotton apparel today was blamed on the practice of gray goods mills becoming their own converters and selling their output only to the "select few."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--By a vote of 344 to 15, the House today passed a Senate-approved bill providing for the appointment of United States representatives to the United Nations Organization...

The triumphant return of Chiang Kai-shek to Nanking, from which he was forced to take flight eight years ago, marks a milepost in the history of the East. When an enemy army stormed through the gates of the old...

LONDON, Dec. 18--More than 6,000 United States troops who were scheduled to arrive in the United States by Christmas appeared destined for disappointment tonight as a result of gales that have been lashing the Atlantic and the coasts of Europe since Sunday.

Edward C. Carter, president of Russian Relief, Inc., who recently returned from a visit to the Soviet Union, declared last night at a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the New York Committee for Russian Relief that the desire to march forward on all major issues with the...

A "housewarming" for a New York doll house was held yesterday at the Museum of the City of New York as part of its Christmas celebration. Designed and executed by the late Carrie Walter Strettheimer, and presented to the museum by her sister, Miss Ettie...

LONDON, Dec. 18--More than 6,000 United States troops who were scheduled to arrive in the United States by Christmas appeared destined for disappointment tonight as a result of gales that have been lashing the Atlantic and the coasts of Europe since Sunday.

Carter, president of Russian Relief, Inc., who recently returned from a visit to the Soviet Union, declared last night at a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the New York Committee for Russian Relief that the desire to march forward on all major issues with the...

A "housewarming" for a New York doll house was held yesterday at the Museum of the City of New York as part of its Christmas celebration. Designed and executed by the late Carrie Walter Strettheimer, and presented to the museum by her sister, Miss Ettie...

Oregon and Oklahoma, the vanguard of a small army of college quintets from afar coming here for the annual jamboree of intersectional basketball double-headers, will oppose Long Island University and City College, respectively, tonight at Madison Square Garden. Needless to say, by this time, there will be a full house of 18,000.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 19--A preview of the kind of defense that is being prepared by the twenty-one German war leaders on trial before the International Military Tribunal was given today with the disclosure of the witnesses they want to call, together ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The United States plans to convert part of its remaining stocks of property abroad into a self-perpetuating scholarship fund, which will bring foreign students to this country, and finance studies of Americans abroad, on a ...

Dr. Frank G. Boudreau, director of the Milbank Memorial Fund, told the annual meeting of the New York Academy of Sciences at the Hotel Astor last night that lasting peace and prosperity depended upon international cooperation in world food planning to deal with the problems of poverty and malnutrition wherever they appear.

Underwriters headed by the Mellon Securities Corporation won yesterday the award of an issue of $2,840,000 of Richmond, Va., public improvement bonds due on Jan. 1, 1947 to 1966. The bid was 100.95, and the interest designated was 1 per cent.

THE wars of art seem almost as violent sometimes as the arts of war. You can get peo ple so heated up over whether the followers of Picasso are better painters than the followers of Sargent, whether an apple by Cezanne is more important than a madonna by Raphael, that they sound like combatants firing over canvas barricades.

CHUNGKING, Dec. 19 (AP)--The contending Nationalist and Chinese Communist leaders were reported ready today to "go the limit" with peace concessions to impress Gen. George C. Marshall, United States envoy, who arrives at Shanghai tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The Government must continue its program for the direction of wool fabrics to manufacturers of men's clothing if returning veterans are to be adequately clothed, John D. Small, Civilian Production Administrator, stated today.

Tonight's events: Puccini's "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 o'clock; concert by Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Bruno Walter conducting, with Rudolph Firkusny, pianist, as assisting artist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; concert ...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Thirty-four employes of the Dallas Railway and Terminal Company threw a figurative bombshell today into an otherwise uneventful hearing by the Securities and Exchange Commission by filing a pe- ...

The heaviest December snowstorm in a dozen years blanketed the entire northeast section of the country yesterday, extending as far south as Macon, Ga., and as far west as Chicago. In New York City more than eight inches of snow had fallen up to late ...

Failure or refusal of the United States to take action can amount in practice to intervention in the affairs of other American republics, Spruille Braden, assistant secretary of State, declared here last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Two of the "broad lines" which the President told Congress should be followed, if it shall approve his plan for a single Department of National Defense, attracted as much interest here today as the major conclusion of the message itself. These were his recommendations (1) of a ...
In memory of a dead comrade, a fighting man gave $5 yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund. A letter with the donation read:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--President Truman's message advocating unification of the Army and Navy was received with joy today by supporters and with wrath by opponents in Congress.

Thousands of home-coming GI's hopeful of spending Christmas with their families, were delayed by the heavy snow storm that struck the Eastern Seaboard yesterday. Many ships lay at anchor for hours near Ambrose Lightship ...

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora issued a permanent injunction yesterday barring a continuation of the month-old strike at the New York Hospital of members of the Building and Construction Trades Council Maintenance Organization, American Federation of Labor.

The Pabst Brewing Company, of Milwaukee, announced yesterday through its president, Harris Perlstein, the purchase of the Hoffman Beverage Company, of Newark. Rudolf Pabst has been elected president of the latter company, which will continue to ...

An ex-soldier who had gone into business for himself as a truckman was a victim yesterday of thieves who stole his one-and-a-half-ton former Army truck with its load of 150 Christmas trees, abruptly bending the veteran's venture.

The former Prime Minister makes a stimulating guest. We shall be glad to see him after the turn of the year. His projected visit is described as a vacation, and he has disavowed any plans for a three-month lecture tour, as rumor earlier had it, but he is welcome ...

Both in fighting shape and brimming with confidence, Tony Janaro, Youngstown, Ohio, welterweight, and Humberto Zavala, Mexican dynamo, yesterday completed training for the eight-round bout in which they are to engage tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19-- Carol Reed, the English director ("Night Train" and "The Stars Look Down"), will come to Hollywood some time in January, to direct his first American film, "Portrait in Black," the screen version of the Ivan Goff-Ben Roberts murder melodrama, which Jack H. Skirball and Bruce Manning are to produce for Universal.

LONDON, Dec. 19--The last major issue before the United Nations Preparatory Commission was resolved today when a subcommittee agreed to have the Assembly call on the mandatory powers "to act in concert" with the other states directly concerned to undertake practical steps for the writing of trust agreements.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Counsel for two Maryland trainers gained a delay today when the State Racing Commission announced that hearings on charges of stimulation of horses at the recent Pimlico meeting had been postponed indefinitely.

RALSTON, N.J., Dec. 19--Lieut. Col. Edward J. Langford, retired civil engineer and veteran of two wars, who was chief engineer of the old New York, Westchester Boston Railroad before the first World War and had held many other important posts, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday in his home here. His age was 78.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 17 (Delayed)--Maj. Gen. Archer L. Lerch, newly appointed military governor in Korea, today conferred with Maj. Gen. A.V. Arnold, who has been acting as military governor since Sept. 8.

LONDON, Dec. 19--Transport planes for use on Britain's nationalized airlines represent one item that will not be acquired in the United States, loan or no loan, if Parliament approves the Government's policy for post-war civil aviation as outlined in a White Paper issued tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The General Motors Corporation will refuse to present its case before President Truman's fact-finding board if that three-man body decides that prices and profits are ...

CHELSEA, Mass., Dec. 19-- Freedom for Mrs. Rose Carlan will be sought in the Chelsea District Court tomorrow, her counsel said tonight, following a preliminary report by the medical examiner that her six-month-old son, Ronald, died of asphyxiation and acute respiratory infection.

A plan for lengthening 155 stations of the IRT division of the city subway, to accommodate tencar trains and thus speed service, became known yesterday from figures transmitted to the City Club of New York by the Board of Transportation.

ALBANY, Dec. 19--Irwin Steingut, Democratic leader of the Assembly and chief target of the recent grand jury investigation of the Legislature, asked the Assembly today to make its own investigation into his affairs.

In one of the largest realty transactions in the midtown area in some time, the Nelson Tower Building, a forty-eight-story office and mercantile building at 450 Seventh Avenue, northwest corner of Thirty-fourth Street, has been sold by the Nelson Towers Realty...

Chip of the Old Block: Thirtyone-year-old George M. Cohan Jr., recently discharged from the Army, is eager to follow in the footsteps of his late dad as a producer and actor. Before proceeding any further, let us take time out to wish the young man, who will be making his local debut as a producer-actor, the same degree of success his renowned father enjoyed--no more, no less.

The $4,000,000 campaign of the Memorial Cancer Fund has raised $1,001,605 in the first two weeks of the drive, it was announced yesterday by S. Sloan Colt, cochairman of the fund with Lewis W. Douglas.

The marriage of Miss Martha Falconer Jones of 18 East Fiftyfourth Street, daughter of Col. Ralph A. Jones, USA (retired), of Jamestown, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Jones, to Albert E. Morgan Jr., son of Mrs. Morgan, also of this city, and the late Mr. Morgan, ...
The ideal things for a girl to wear on a flying tour of Latin America are "switcheroos," according to Betty Betz, who is about to start off on such a tour. Her own interchangeable wardrobe was ...

BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP)--After being held to three straight deadlocks, the Bruins returned to the National Hockey League's victory column by topping the New York Rangers, 8--7, tonight before a blizzard-defying crowd of 9,424 at the Boston Garden. Herbie Cain caged the winning goal with only forty-one seconds to play.

The nation's carpet and rug manufacturers probably will reach their 1941 rate of production late in 1946, Leroy A. Beers, president of the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, predicted yesterday in an address at the organization's annual membership meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria.

Columbia's basketball team fought off a determined Princeton quintet during the second half of the Eastern Intercollegiate League game on the Lion's court last night, drawing ahead seven times after the Tigers tied the score to take their first league start, 46--44, in the closing minute of play.

The report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for the first nine months of this year, issued yesterday by Col. Sosthenes Behn, president, showed a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes, depre- ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Fathers will no longer be drafted for the armed forces. This order, issued tonight to local boards from headquarters of the Selective Service System, has the effect of excusing from 300 to 400 men from military service each month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The Navy reacted quickly today to President Truman's approval of the Army plan for reorganization of the armed services by ordering all officers to stop making statements in public opposing unification, unless they are called as witnesses before Congressional committees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Veterans are beginning to encounter difficulties in finding employment, with the full impact of discharges upon the labor market yet to be felt, the Department of Commerce said today in this month's issue of its Survey of Current Business.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--By the close vote of 31--30 the Senate rejected today the Administration recommendation that the Second War Powers Act, containing authorities for priority distributions ...

Charges of double-dealing were made yesterday against Mayor La Guardia, the Port of New York Authority and the City Planning Commission in a brief filed with the latter agency by five constituent companies of the Greyhound bus system.

Expansion programs of Valentine Co., manufacturers of Valspar paints and varnishes, will mean a 100 per cent increase in the capacity of its Brooklyn plant, Frank P. Connolly, vice president and sales manager, stated yesterday at a sales meeting in the Hotel Park Central.

A new contract raising the pay scales of 25,000 workers employed in 140 of the city's hotels from 25 to 40 per cent was signed yesterday between the Hotel Association of New York City and the New York Hotel Trades Council, American Federation of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Congress gave its final approval today to the legislation making the United States an active, working force in the United Nations Organization, and President Truman, ...

Since V-J Day nearly four million soldiers, nearly one million sailors and a considerable number of marines have been released from service. There remain several millions who are still on sea duty or stationed in Europe, Japan, on the Asiatic mainland and at our scattered island outposts.

St. Paul's School of Concord, N.H., will pay its annual visit here for a hockey game today when it faces Deerfield Academy of Deerfield, Mass., at Madison Square Garden. The face-off is scheduled for 3 P.M. Proceeds of the contest will go to the St. Paul's School Camp for Underprivileged Boys, located at Danbury, N.H.

An appeal to President Truman to allots the shipment of clothing, bedding and shoes into Germany to help those in dire need, particularly homeless evacuees, has been made by the Church Committee one Overseas Relief and Reconstruction, Leslie B. Toss, director, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 19--With the exception of a Government-held enclave around Rezaieh, near the frontier of Turkish Kurdistan, the coup detat of the new autonomous government in Iranian Azerbaijan tonight appears to be about complete.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 19-- Stephen Van Rensselaer, author, antique collector and authority on early American firearms for fifty years, died here on Monday in the historic house where he lived. His age was 74.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Robert P. Patterson, Secretary of War, paid tribute to the "untiring efforts" and "unfaltering courage" of the Army chaplains at a luncheon today of the Committee on Army and Navy Religious Activities of the National Jewrish Welfare Board.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--President Truman called on Congress today to combine the Army and Navy into a single Department of National Defense, with coequal status for the land, sea and air forces.

Despite appeals from civic and governmental agencies there are unused houses in the city whose owners do not seem to respond to the critical nature of the housing shortage, City Housing Commissioner Joseph Platzker said in an interview yesterday.

The former Scoville School, a six-story building on a lot 28 by 100 feet at 1008 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the southeast corner of Eightysecond Street, was resold by Frederick Brown to a client of Henry Baker. It is assessed at $135,000 and will be altered into doctor's suites.

The establishment of the International Film Foundation, described as a non-profit organization to "promote better understanding between peoples of different nations, races and religions" through the ...

Opposition by defense counsel to evidence and testimony submitted before the three-man Board of Education committee hearing the case of Miss May A. Quinn, suspended teacher accused of "intolerance and un-Americanism," marked the resumption of the trial yesterday in the hall of the board at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

Convertible preferred stock of La Consolidada, S.A., a Mexican concern which manufactures steel and metal products, will be offered today to American investors by a group of underwriters headed by Shields Co.

ROSELLE PARK, N.J., Dec. 19 --Mayor Louis V. Ebert, civic leader here for many years and an attorney in New York and New Jersey, died here early today in his home at 425 Chestnut Street, after a long illness.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP)--A halfdozen Midwestern athletes, who already have completed three years of varsity competition, today were handed a stay of eligibility execution by the Big Ten.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Dec. 17 (Delayed)--Tabulators, typewriters and card index systems by the dozens in the prosaic office atmosphere of a huge red brick building in Hoechst, a suburb of Frankfort, are recording daily the most poignant chapters of the war's aftermath.

Without Carl Meinhold, dropped Monday on account of scholastic difficulties, Long Island University's basketball team floundered helplessly at Madison Square Garden last night, bowing to court-wise Oregon, which knew where the ball belonged and put it there often enough to inflict a 60-50 defeat on Claire Bee's Blackbirds.

ALBANY, Dec. 19--Governor Dewey and the State War Council, acting under their emergency powers, made available today $1,950,000 of State funds fox the swift conversion of existing facilities, ranging from military bases to ships, into temporary housing.

Coming in time to affect the cost of the Christmas dinner, reductions in ceiling prices were announced yesterday by the Office of Price Administration on dressed heavy turkeys, frying and broiling chickens, light fowl, apples, green peas and loose carrots.

PELHAM, N.Y., Dec. 19--Miss Anne Shepard Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Moore of Pelham Manor, was married this evening to Ensign James McGough Kiberd, USNR, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Kiberd Jr. of ...

LONDON, Dec. 19--German workers are reverting to national type and advocating the same kind of trade union set-up that resulted in the destruction of their organizations under the Nazi regime, leaders reported today.

Hank Greenberg, a 34-year-olds inspiration to every returning G.I., staged the biggest come-back in sports in 1945 with a grand-slam home run that won the pennant for Detroit on the last day of the season and with his slugging for the victorious Tigers in the world series.

LONDON, Dec. 19--With some of her plates dented and a steel curtain protecting one of the hangars carried away, the United States aircraft carrier Wasp took refuge in Plymouth Harbor today from the buffeting of the Atlantic storm.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Congress gave final approval today of the appropriation of $750,000,000 as a first instalment of this country's second-year contribution to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, but tied it up in a general deficiency appropriation bill which is still in dispute between the houses.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 19--The Army and Navy ordered further reductions today in discharge requirements and these will make an additional 837,000 personnel eligible for return to civilian life between Dec. 31 and Feb. 2.

Although winning only three of eight events, Brooklyn Tech had enough seconds and thirds to defeat Jamaica, 37 to 30, at the Seward Park pool yesterday and capture its second straight P.S. A.L. swimming championship.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP)--The Chicago Black Hawks came from behind twice and held a lead twice but had to settle for a 4-4 tie with the Montreal Canadiens, leaders of the National Hockey League, in a first-place battle before 15,812 fans tonight.

Brokers on the trading floor of the Stock Exchange yesterday, many of whom missed the opening because of delayed commuter service from urban areas, recalled the heavy snow fall on Feb. 20, 1934, which necessitated an 11 o'clock opening for the same but more inclement reason.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 19 --Vice Premier George Tatarescu is waging a campaign with Communist backing to succeed Petru Groza as Premier, according to a usually reliable source, and his ...

The board of directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation are charting a new national advertising campaign with considerable flexibility allowed to local regional offices, it was learned yesterday. All advertisements will originate in Washington, but regional offices are to be given the option of substituting items of particular interest for special local coverage.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 19 (AP)--Although Job Jessop, who leads the nation's jockeys this season, chalked up victories No. 282 and 283, it was Ted Atkinson, the 1944 champion, who won today's Everglades Purse, on Mrs. H. Mart's lightly played filly, Lucky Aunt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Representative Robert L. Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said today that he could see no prospect of substantial tax reductions until we have "a balanced budget or a near-balanced budget."

Savings bank funds will provide 1,700 new apartments in redevelopment projects in Manhattan and Brooklyn to cost nearly $12,000,000 as initial steps by these institutions to pool their resources and help to meet the city's post-war housing needs, according to plans that crystallized yesterday.

Four new books with subjectmatter almost as diversified as the outdoors field itself have reached this department in recent weeks. They range from a handy reference book on fish, both fresh and salt water, to a volume of humor that is really humorous.

AL SCHACHT hasn't collected the bet as yet but at least he gave it a sporting try. It began in October of 1944 when the Clown Prince of Baseball was in Milne Bay, which is not located in Staten Island. The captain of a naval vessel discussed the war with that distinguished military expert, Mr. Schacht. "The war won't end before 1947," said the captain somberly.

Plans for a tall store and office building to occupy the blockfront on the east side of Park Avenue, from Fifty-sixth to Fifty-seventh Streets, were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the site, which had been in the same ownership for seventy-five years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Development of a new twin-engine land plane, the P2V, Neptune, which it described as the "farthest ranging, fastest and most heavily armed patrol and search bomber yet developed," was announced by the Navy Department today.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week rose 2,039,000 barrels, to 89,043,000, compared with 82,996,000 a year ago, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies of light fuel oil, however, ...

The cast of the well-rounded, handsomely staged performance given Gounod's "Romeo et Juliette" last night at the Metropolitan differed in two important respects from that of the previous presentation this season.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 19--As an aftermath of the grand jury investigation into gambling in Nassau County that began last Aug. 10, six members of the Nassau County Police Department formerly attached to the Woodmere Precinct who faced departmental charges have resigned, Police Commissioner John M. Beckmann disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)-- The House approved today a Senate-passed resolution calling on the Government to "use its good offices" with Britain to permit free entry of Jews into Palestine. Action was on a voice vote, after members refused, 133 to 36, to send the measure back to committee.

RUTLAND, Vt., Dec. 19-- Maj. Gen. Leonard F. Wing, who led the colorful Forty-third Division (Winged Victory) through four brilliant campaigns in the Pacific, died of a heart attack here this morning at his home.

Plans for the Roosevelt Memorial Concert, which will replace the President's Birthday Ball as a tribute to the late Franklin Delano Roosevelt and as a source of funds for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, were revealed yesterday at a meeting of the Roosevelt Memorial Concert Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Dec. 19--The British have decided to expropriate the coal and steel industries of the Ruhr, it was reliably reported in London tonight. Formal announcement will be made Friday by the military authorities in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach sought tonight to end the forty-nine-day strike of Pennsylvania and Central Greyhound Bus Lines by appointing a fact-finding board to investigate the wage dispute.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The leading members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have told the Administration that they believe Soviet Russia must agree to open her atomic bomb laboratories and factories to international inspection before we disclose any more important information to her about the bomb.

A combination "three-ring circus" and Christmas carol songfest was staged yesterday by fifty children, 6 to 11 years old, in the tinsel-trimmed gymnasium of the Henry Street Settlement at 301 Henry Street. An audience of 300 youngsters applauded, whistled and cheered.

PARIS, Dec. 19--Jean Giraudoux's posthumous play, "La Folle de Chaillot," staged by Louis Jouvet at the Athenee Theatre, scene of the author's previous successes, drew an ovation from an audience of elite at a critics' dress rehearsal here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--A Navy court-martial failed today to state a finding on charges that Capt. Charles B. McVay 3d, negligently hazarded the cruiser Indianapolis by failing to follow a zigzag course on the night she was sunk.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 19 (AP)-- Congress passed a broad revision of the GI Bill of Rights today. Rules on loans and education for veterans were revised.

Paul Raibourn, president of Television Products, Inc., and head of television activities for Paramount Pictures, Inc., denied yesterday that he or the corporations had hindered development of television, as charged in a civil anti-trust suit filed by the Government in Federal court Tuesday.
Though our most recent tour of city stores revealed rapidly dwindling stocks, with no commensurate decrease in traffic, a last-minute round-up of gift suggestions might benefit the tardy shopper.

The War Shipping Administration's battle against a seasonal shortage of merchant seamen lost ground yesterday with a rise in the number of crewbound merchant ships from sixty-six to ninety on the Atlantic Coast alone, Capt. Hewlett R. Bishop, WSA, Atlantic ...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Evidence suggesting that there was no accepted understanding in the Navy Department in 1941 as to the specific responsibility for sending information to the fleet command- ...

The New York Yankees of the new All-America Conference offered a $25,000 guarantee yesterday to any clubs of the rival National Football League for exhibition games here next fall, The United Press reported.

The French Government has sent formal notes to both Washington and London proposing consultations between the three Governments on breaking off diplomatic relations with Franco Spain and recognizing the Spanish Republican Government in ...

The corrective movement on the stock market made more progress yesterday, but trading proceeded at such a dull pace as to make meaningless the net results of the day. While the composite industrial price showed only a fractional increase, the strongest spots ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Winston Churchill, former Prime Minister of Great Britain, who is planning a visit to the United States early next year, will deliver an address on "World Affairs" and spend a number of weeks in Florida.
After holding in a comparatively narrow range, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 1 point higher to 7 points lower than on Tuesday.

Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Administrator of Veterans Affairs, told 1,000 members of the Life Underwriters Association meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday afternoon that speedy demobilization of service men, which is "not ...

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $2,569,694 for the three months ended on Oct. 31, or $1.23 a share on the common stock. For the corresponding three months of last year, the net profit was $2,020,818, or 97 cents a share.

President Truman has presented to Congress his plan for unification of the military services. He recommends the creation of a Department of National Defense. It would be headed by a civilian secretary of Cabinet rank.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 19--Attorney General Tom C. Clark, addressing the convention of the American Bar Association here today, declared that the time had come for "business, in its two great subdivisions of labor and management, to cooperate with government."
TOKYO, Dec. 19--While Japanese officials continued to emphasize the growing gravity of the impending food crisis, occupation authorities moved tonight to forbid Americans to eat Japanese food.

LONDON, Dec. 19--Reflecting relief at the approval of the AngloAmerican loan agreement and the Bretton Woods bill by the House of Lords, stock markets today were more cheerful. Gilt-edge securities improved, as did some of the more popular industrials.

The Civilian Production Administration automatically should attack a CCC priority rating to every export license issued for products in short supply, members of the international trade forum conducted at the Waldorf-Astoria by the International Trade Section of the New York Board of Trade, Inc., ...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The United States in a statement issued by the State Department today urged all parties in the Netherlands Indies to resume at an ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The British Government has demanded that Siam supply between 1,000,000 and 1,500,000 tons of rice to other countries in Southeast Asia as "restitution" for the part she played in the war, it was learned today.

While the average small on medium-size manufacturer and converter is operating on fractional quotas of fabrics, apparently there is no shortage of cottonpiece goods at job finishing plants in the East, it was learned yesterday from textile men who asserted ...

LONDON, Dec. 19--John Amery, profligate son and traitor to his country, was hanged this morning at Wandsworth Prison by Henry Pierrepoint, the senior hangman, fresh from his execution of the eleven Nazis at Belsen last Friday. It was the ending of a human tragedy that aroused more pity ...

Only fifteen Representatives could be rounded up on Tuesday to vote against the bill setting up machinery for United States participation in the United Nations Organization. In the Senate two weeks earlier seven members opposed the measure.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 21--Judge Thomas F. Meaney in Federal Court today imposed fines totalling $5,200 on twenty-four dining car and other employes of the Erie Railroad who had pleaded guilty to conspiracy to defraud the road in interstate commerce. The defendants diverted meats and other scarce foods from dining cars and sold them at black-market levels.

A Yuletide concert by the New York Athletic Club glee club will be presented tomorrow at 3 P.M. in the club's gymnasium.

Stockholders of the McCrory Stores Corporation approved yesterday an amendment to the certificate of incorporation authorizing 80,000 shares of a new class of $100 par preferred stock and increasing authorized $1 par common shares from 1,250,000 to 1,400,000.

Nine athletes--eight men and a woman--have been named by the Amateur Athletic Union as final candidates for the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy, awarded annually to the country's outstanding amateur.
A program for shipping tinned foods to European families suffering starvation this winter is in production under the supervision of the Unitarian Service Committee, it was announced yesterday.
Lawrence A. Witkins, retired director oP foreign languages for this city's public school system, died yesterday in his home at 54 Morningside Drive. His age was 67.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Dec 24 --An autopsy is to be performed here to determine the cause of death of Mrs. Rita Murray, 32 years old, of 184 Mercer street, this city. Her frozen body was found yesterday morning inside the gate of a stable yard at 40 Gilchrist Street.

Now that peace has come once more to a war-weary world, this country is set for a tremendous sports boom that may overshadow even the terrific Twenties, sports writers from coast to coast agreed yesterday in a poll conducted by The Associated Press.

RIO DE JANEIRRO, Dec. 24-- Traders, department stores, curio shops, grocery stores, jewelry shops and fashion stores reported today that Christmas sales this year surpassed any in Brazil's retailing history.
Charles L. Ellis, formerly lighting consultant with the McBethEvans division of Corning Glass Works in the New York area, has been named New York manager of the Pittsburgh Reflector Company.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 24--Newark Airport, one of the world's largest commercial air fields before its occupation by the Army in 1942, will return officially to commercial aviation on Feb. 3, with service by six airlines, the City Commission announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 -- The Rev. Richard A. Gleeson, Jesuit educator, died last night of pneumonia in St. Joseph's Infirmary at the University of San Francisco, after suffering a stroke. He would have become 84 years old today.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 24-- Mrs. William Edwin Coffin Nazro of this place, formerly of Plymouth, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Virginia Dupee, to Gaylord Parks, son of Mrs. Francis Robert Parks of Chestnut Hill and the late Mr. Parks. The wedding is planned for March 21.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP)--Signing for the 1946 season of Tackle Bill Hempel, skipper of a Navy PT boat in seven Pacific invasions, was announced today by the Chicago Bears. Hempel, former Carrol College (Wis.) star, played briefly for the Bears in 1942 before he was called to sea duty.

Dr. Harold W. Stiegler, recently promoted to the rank of lieutenant colonel after three years in the Army as chief, protective division, technical command, has been appointed a full-time director of research for the American Association...

Mrs. Ada S. Best of Wilton and Greenwich, Conn., died Sunday at the LeRoy Sanitarium, 40 East Sixty-first Street. She was the widow of Herman D. Best. A daughter, Mrs. Harold N. Munger, and a brother, Edward W. Case, both of New York, survive.

A snow pile in the rear yard of 114 Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn, may have saved the life of Mrs. Anna Maher, 69 years old, yesterday when she lost her balance while cleaning a third floor window and fell inte the snow. She suffered only minor facial injuries.
Henry F. Gardner, District Attorney of Sullivan County, N. Y., for three terms, 1917 to 1926, died here on Sunday in the Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 56.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 24--The Government is lifting its ban on private flying, which has existed since September, 1939, the Defense Ministry announced today. The administration is also planning the sale, through the War Assets Realization Board, of the light transport planes that it took over from flying clubs and private owners.

Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for common stock of Fansteel Metallurgical Corp. Manufacturers Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for new 4 per cent preferred stock of Howard Stores Corporation.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 24 (AP)--John G. Crommelin, a planter, whose five sons were all graduated from the Naval Academy at Annapolis, died today after a brief illness, at the age of 72. He had suffered a hip fracture two weeks ago.

Radio programs today will feature Christmas "pick-up" broadcasts from all over the world, with particular emphasis on two-way conversations between service men still abroad and their families at home.

Newspaper funds for aid to individuals have had a banner year, a survey yesterday indicated. The annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York, conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES, Stands on Christmas morning at $288,874.10, compared with $243,078.20 ion Christmas Day of 1944.

Two Queens Republicans, Senator Seymour Halpern and Assemblyman Fred W. Preller, will seek cancellation of 1945 State income taxes when the Legislature convenes at Albany next month, Senator Halpern said yesterday.

A 5-weeks-old girl narrowly escaped death by asphyxiation yesterday when her mother's cold prevented her from immediately smelling gas fumes after a pot of water boiled over on a kitchen stove and extinguished the flame, police of the Clinton Street Station reported.

Standing at Madison Avenue and Fifty-second Street with her mother and younger brother after a Christmas party, Jacqueline Landt, 5 years old, was grabbed up yesterday by a man who started to flee with her, He had barely got across the avenue with her when the child's father and uncle overtook him and halted his flight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24--Constantin Brun, former Danish Minister to the United States, died here last night. He had been serving as honorary counselor to the legation at his death. His age was 85.

HANKOW, Dec. 24 (AP)--This once-flourishing treaty-port city, still without electricity or adequate tap water, is wide open to further epidemics such as the recent smallpox outbreak, which took 200 lives.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24--In a ceremony in which the National Community Christmas tree was lighted for the first time since 1941, President Truman told the people of the United States today that we must not fail or falter though the victories of peace will be "no less hard won than success at arms."
All good Americans today are adding to their joys and merriment by adding to the happiness and comfort of others.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Dec. 24 (AP)--Brig. Gen. Stephen H. Sherrill, 52 years old, commanding general of the Eastern Signal Corps Training Center here since Jan. 3, 1945, retires today from that post and will retire from active Army service. He will be succeeded by Col. Hugh Mitchell, former commandant of the Eastern Signal Corps schools.

Abandoned with the surrounding tenements since June this year, old Public School 104 at 415 East Sixteenth Street was wrecked by flames yesterday before it could become the prey of wreckers whc are to clear the area for the Stuyvesant Town housing project.

LONDON, Dec. 24 (U.P)--Former King Peter of Yugoslavia, his hopes of ascending the throne dashed by the powers' recognition of the Yugoslav Republic, left for his country home today and an informed source said he intended to remain in England.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Dec. 24-- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Miller Minton of North Hills have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Lois, to Cpl. Richard Nevins, AAF, son of Mrs. William McCay of Pasadena, Calif., and the late Richard Nevins.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24--United Air Lines has appointed Al Button, Eastern region superintendent of mechanical operations at Chicago for the last year, as assistant superintendent of maintenance in San Francisco. Ted Kramer, with United since 1933, will succeed Mr. Button.

Louis P. Goldberg, Brooklyn, and Ira J. Palestin, of the Bronx, successful candidates of the Liberal party for the City Council, were sworn in yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null in the County Court House.

BERLIN, Dec. 24 (AP)--The notice in a German public building said. "Coffins available only for those who died of infectious disease." Near by was a cardboard angel proclaiming "Merry Christmas--Peace on Earth, Good Will Toward Men."

The Long Island Railroad gave its passengers a Christmas present yesterday in the form of delayed arrivals for the usual fares. The gift, however, was not received in true holiday spirit by the thousands of recipients.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 24 (Netherlands News Agency)--A virtually complete list of Japanese atrocities in Java, including the names of almost all war criminals and the methods of torture that each made his specialty, has been compiled by the War CrimeS Investigation Commission here after weeks of laborious work.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP)--The annual international swimming forum, halted during the war, will be resumed in 1946 with an eleven-day meet beginning Dec. 22, it was decided today by Chamber of Commerce representatives and members of the National College Swimming Coaches Association.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 24 --Government employes will receive a holiday from today to Jan. 6. All Government offices will be closed.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 24 (Reuter) --Two British officers have been murdered by Egyptian fishermen, police authorities in Cairo said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (U.P.)-- Gen Dwight D. Eisenhower, Army Chief of Staff, accompanied by Maj. Gen. Alexander B. Surles, today paid a two-hour visit to Walter Reed Hospital here.

C., who will be administrator of King's College, a new school being established by Holy Cross congregation at Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer has reduced the assessed valuations on 930 Park Avenue, aggregating $1,460,000 for the tax years 1943-44 and 1944-45, to $936,000, a cut of $524,000, or more than 35 per cent. Paul E. Illman, vice president of Pease Elliman, Inc., was realty expert for the owner, and Henry H. Harkavy, acted as attorney.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 24-- Katharine Hepburn and Robert Taylor have been named by MetroGoldwyn-Mayer for the leads in "You Were There," a film to be based on the novel of the same title by Thelma Strabel. Vincent Minnelli will direct the psychological triangle drama and Pandro Berman will be the producer.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 24 (AP) --Mrs. Margaret S. Burnham, widow of D. H. Burnham, noted Chicagoan, who was architect for the Chicago World's Fair of 1893, died here last night, at the age of 95.
Merle A. Yockey has been elected a vice president of the Pfeiffer Brewing Company, Detroit, Mich., succeeding Carleton S. Smith, who has resigned, it was announced yesterday.

Over 2,200 veterans have received assistance in establishing their own apparel businesses from the Apparel Accessories Advisory Board for War Veterans, which works in close cooperation with the Veterans Service Center, 10 East Fortieth Street, Joseph Love, board chairman, reported yesterday.

BETHLEHEM, Tuesday, Dec. 25 --Again the spotlight of the world was on Bethlehem this morning when privileged pilgrims, who came in manner of the Magi to worship at the Shrine where Christ was born, gathered at the Nativity Grotto to pay homage on His birthday. It is probably one of the most dramatic scenes in history, this commemoration of the Christ Child's birth.

ALBANY, Dec. 24 (AP)--Unemployed workers claiming unemployment insurance benefits in the State in the week ended Dec. 7 totaled 239,730, an increase of 5,147 from the previous week, the Labor Department reported today.

The world-wide shortage of Scotch whisky is prompting American distillers to pay much more attention to advertising promotion in their foreign markets, liquor trade sources reported yesterday.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 25--In bombed-out Nuremberg, once the center of Europe's mechanical toy industry, there was not a single store this year where Santa Claus could do his shopping. Tailors advertised alterations of old clothing as Christmas gifts.

PEIPING, Dec. 25 (U.P.)--The increasing tempo of penetration of Manchuria by Chinese Central Government troops indicated today they would take over Mukden and Harbin from the Russians by New Year's Day. Chinese newspapers attributed the speed-up to "a friendlier attitude on the part of the Soviet."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (U.P.)-- Mrs. George S. Patton Jr. returned here today by Army plane from Hamm, Luxembourg, where she attended the funeral yesterday of her husband, the former Third Army Commander.

Francisco Franco's Government. His speech was constantly interrupted with shouts of "Franco! Franco! Franco!"

THE NEW YORK TIMES fund for the Hundred Neediest Cases has climbed to a record sum this year. More money is still pouring in.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--A.F. Hinrichs, Acting Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said today that unemployment was far less serious than was expected before V-J Day, but that production in many lines was picking up "only slowly."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)-- Chairman Cannon of the House Appropriations Committee said today that Congressional leaders had agreed to speed legislation next year in efforts to "close up shop" from July 1 through the November elections. WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--High wages for the worker are a necessity for the year, 1946, William Green and Philip Murray, respective heads of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, asserted in New Year statements today. Both held that such a goal was mandatory for the nation's economic advancement.

The Board of Education's trial of Miss May A. Quinn, suspended teacher of civics accused of displaying an "un-American, intolerant and undemocratic attitude" in her classes at Junior High School 227, Brooklyn, ended yesterday after four days of testimony and an eleven-day recess, with Miss Quinn taking the stand to deny the accusations made against her by witnesses at earlier hearings.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 2--The marriage of Miss Mary Hamilton Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Jenkins Lee of Baltimore, to Outerbridge Horsey of Washington, son of Mrs. Outerbridge Horsey of New York and Southampton, L.I., and the late Mr. Horsey, took place here this morning in the Roman Catholic Cathedral.

The information that President-elect Dutra of Brazil, whose country will be host to the forthcoming Pan-American Conference, is in favor of convening the Conference on the first possibly date--March 15--is good news.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 8 (AP)--Bob Feller, speedball king of the major leagues, announced an all-star roster of instructors for his exservice men's baseball school today after signing the "best" one-year contract of his career with the, Indians.

CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 8--Creswell Maclaughlin, former newspaper editor and well-known after-dinner speaker, died here yesterday in Cornwall Hospital. He was 81 years old.
A skilled and sensitive keeper of the flames is a person of patience and understanding. It may be that in the bright, chromium-plated future homes will be heated by means as yet barely discerned.
AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 8 (AP)--Mrs. Gertrude Penfield Seiberling, nationally known as a patron of music, wife of Frank A. Seiberling, a pioneer in the rubber industry, died today at the age of 80.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--A group of young Siamese students who left American campuses in March, 1943, were back in this country today and told how they operated a secret service in Siam that enabled American agents to commute almost nightly into Bangkok, their country's capital.
LONDON, Jan. 8--Britain will propose that the whole refugee problem, including that of the Jews, be taken on by the United Nations Organization, Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin said today.

Bruno Walter, as guest leader of the Philadelphia Orchestra, gave some of the greatest performances we have ever heard from him last night in Carnegie Hall. He interpreted Brahms, Haydn and Mahler. Alexander Knox's portrayal of the title role in Twentieth CenturyFox's film biography, "Wilson," was voted the best male starring performance of 1945 in the fifth annual national poll of newspaper, magazine and radio film reviewers ...
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 8--The formation of an underground movement in Azerbaijan to combat the new autonomous, government was reported today by an Iranian official who arrived from Teheran.
The long active connection of Jackson E. Reynolds with the First National Bank of New York has been ended, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.

Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, yesterday accused Price Administrator Chester Bowles of conducting a "malicious campaign of vilification and lies against retailers of this country."
Jean Gordon, 30 years old, a niece of the late Gen. George S. Patton Jr., was found dead early yesterday morning in the apartment of a woman friend at 157 East Seventy-second Street.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 8 (AP)--Seven minor football rule changes designed to speed up play were selected today by the advisory committee on rules of the American Football Coaches Association from a record list of more than 100 suggestions. No recommendations for major rule revisions were made.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--Aviation problems of the United States and Great Britain will be examined at a civil aviation conference in Bermuda beginning Jan. 15.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 8 (U.P.)-- British troops today began largescale operations against Indonesian extremists in the Semarang area of north central Java, where Indonesian guns have been shelling the Semarang airfield.

Seven thousand Western Union telegraph workers of this city went out on strike yesterday in a move calculated to cut off the "telegraph capital of the world" from communication with the rest of the country, except for governmental and emergency messages.

The story of "Oil--1940-45," recorded in paintings, water colors and drawings as an educational project by well-known American artists, went on exhibition yesterday at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue.

TOKYO, Jan. 9--The number of the hereditary nobility, including the Imperial Family, who are seated in Japan's House of Peers will undergo a drastic reduction under the Government's reform plan approved by the Cabinet yesterday. A new class of membership will be created, peers elected directly from prefectural town and village assemblies.

ALBANY, Jan. 9--As the first action of the new session the Legislature set up a joint committee today on rents to draft legislation extending the commercial rent freeze for New York City and other measures providing for State control of residential rents in the event Federal controls expire.

Anglo-California, San Francisco The Anglo-California National Bank of San Francisco reported as of Dec. 31, 1945, total deposits of $481,553,687 and total assets of $519,462,930, compared, respectively, with $410,186,283 and $448,814,354 on Sept. 29. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $102,062,339, against $82,576,245; holdings of United States Government ...

An investing client of Alfred C. Marks purchased the eleven-story and penthouse apartment building at 11 East Sixty-eighth Street, northwest corner of Madison Avenue, from the Union Dime Savings Bank. Assessed at $860,000, the property is 100 by 120 feet and rents for about $106,878 a year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--With Soviet Russia still not heard from a month after being invited with thirteen other countries to attend a preparatory meeting for an international trade conference, it seemed likely to officials here that the U.S.S.R. would not take part.

The National Football League "probably will discuss" the proposition of not revealing names of college players selected in its draft, as advanced by its infant rival, the All-America Conference, as it opens a four-day session at the Hotel Commodore today, but "sees no reason" to change its policy.

The preliminary annual report of A.M. Byers Company, producer of wrought iron and steel products, showed yesterday a net profit of $1,055,126 for the fiscal year ended with last September, after all charges but including a Federal tax credit of $826,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--Col. George P. Baker, director of the Office of Transport and Communications Policy in the State Department, expressed confidence today that the civil aviation conference which will open in Bermuda Tuesday between the United States and United Kingdom would be successful.

A syndicate headed by the Chemical Bank Trust Company bought yesterday $27,850,000 of $28,100,000 housing authority notes offered by thirteen public agencies, including $8,404,000 San Francisco and $7,048,000 St. Louis. The winning bids ranged from 0.57 to 0.60 per cent. The State Street Trust Company of Boston bought $250,000 Boston Authority notes at 0.56 per cent.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 9--King Ibn Saud, who has transformed himself in twenty years from an obscure desert chieftain into a world political figure, will arrive here tomorrow for a state visit that is regarded here as a major event in the political renaissance of the Arabic world.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9--Edgar L. Warren, chief of the United States Conciliation Service, told Swift and Armour, the two largest packing house companies, today, that the Government would permit higher prices for meat to induce a settlement of the wage dispute and thereby avert a strike called for Wednesday by unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor. He told reporters:

DETROIT, Jan. 9--The KaiserFrazer Corporation signed formally today with the United Automobile Workers. CIO, an agreement providing for company and union security against one another, a production, bonus plan, and wage concessions likely to give workers 25 to 35 per cent more than the highest prevailing rates in the industry.

Postmaster Albert Goldman turned over yesterday to Nelson A. Rockefeller, chairman of the New York City committee of the Victory Clothing Collection, 8,000 pounds of garments taken from unclaimed mail. The presentation was made at the General Post Office, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue.

Widespread disruption developed in the city's commercial life yesterday as the strike of 7,000 Western Union telegraph workers in New York, Long Island and Northern New Jersey continued with no sign of a settlement.

A new 'cello concerto was given its New York premiere last night by the Boston Symphony orchestra under Dr. Koussevitzky's baton in Carnegie Hall. The concerto was Vladimir Dukelsky's. The soloist was Gregor Piatigorsky.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--The Port of New York Authority challenged the Civil Aeronautics Board today to face the issue "of fitting the airplane into the needs of the local community" by requiring adequate local and feeder service between New York City and points in New England.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 9--The last lingering hope that some semblance of peace might obtain in Palestine, at least during the discussions of the joint Anglo-American inqujry committee, was smashed today when the most representative gathering of Arabs in ...

The Rev. Dr. Robbins W. Barstow, director of the Commission for World Council Service, 297 Fourth Avenue, asked President Truman yesterday for immediate action to clear the way for American church relief in Germany.

The Manufacturers Trust Company's net operating earnings for 1945 were $10,107,441, or $4.90 a share on the 2,062,000 shares outstanding at the year-end, compared with $8,011,681, or $4.86 a share in 1944 on the 1,649,992 shares then outstanding, Harvey D. Gibson, president, reported at the annual meeting yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer and other city officials signed an agreement yesterday with the representatives of nine savings banks for the erection of a $4,750,000 housing project to be known as Sedgwick Village at University Avenue and Washington Bridge in the Bronx. Plans call for four buildings to house 700 families in approximately 2,500 rooms.

Telephone installation workers in forty-four States went out on strike yesterday, bringing the threat of a country-wide tie-up of telephone service tomorrow norning, as the United States Conciliation Service pressed efforts to achieve a settlement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--General Eisenhower has ordered all overseas commanders to return to this country "without delay" and regardless of points any troops for whom there was no military need, and in a memorandum to President Truman indicated today that no disciplinary action was planned for soldiers participating in the Manila demonstrations.

Arthur Hopkins' record of accomplishments in the theatre is held in high esteem. Inactive as a Broadway producer for two years, he will return to the fold on Jan. 22, when he escorts "The Magnificent Yankee" into the Royale. His host of friends will be wishing him the best of luck.

More than a thousand persons, including many prominent in public life and hundreds of employes or former employes of The New York Sun, attended a funeral service yesterday afternoon for William T. Dewart Jr., publisher and secretary of The Sun, in St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

ON Jan. 10, 1939, Count Galeazzo Clano, 33 years old. Italian Foreign Minister and road-company Machiavelli, noted in his diary, published today, that things were going well in the Spanish civil war from the Fascist point of view, and a few days later he parroted Mussolini's words, saying that, if France helped the Republican Government, thirty more fascisti battalions would land, "even if it should provoke a European war."

Apropos of club meetings, ice fishing and such: The Putnam County Fish and Game Association will install its slate of officers tomorrow night at a meeting at the County Court House, Carmel, N.Y. William G. Kilcoyne of Carmel is the new president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)-- President Roosevelt wrote Wendell Willkie two days before Pearl Harbor that there might be "an armed clash at any moment with Japan," the Congressional Investigating Committee learned today.
Countee Cullen, Negro poet, died yesterday in Sydenham Hospital. His age was 42.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--The group of young officers on terminal leave, whose effort to serve in a civilian status the Government for which they fought has been previously discussed in this space, have left the capital, their mission a washout. Many have already found private employment as a beginning of their post-war careers, or they have returned to the employment ...

LONDON, Jan. 9--United States Secretary of State James F. Byrnes put an end to the atomic bomb controversy within the United States' United Nations delegation today by announcing that no secrets of the bomb would be given away without Congressional approval.
OTTAWA, Jan. 9 (AP)--Canada's capital cheered in a sleet storm today to welcome Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, United States Army Chief of Staff, on a four-day visit to the Dominion.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9--The Potomac Edison Company'a proposal to sell 63,784 shares of new cumulative preferred stock to refinance a similar number of outstanding preferred shares was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Yale's basketball team poured on the heat in the second half to break up a tight defensive battle and hand the Columbia quintet a 44-to-32 trouncing at the Morningside Heights gymnasium. The triumph made it six in a row for the undefeated Elis.

The Frank M. Hawks Memorial Trophy was awarded yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES and Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher, in recognition of their contributions to the development of aviation. The award, sixth of an annual series, was decided on by a committee of distinguished fliers, past and present, who are members of Air Servent ...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9-- Lew Ayres, Hollywood's most widely known conscientious objector, who, during almost four years war service, won the respect and admiration of his former detractors in the film industry, is returning to the screen.

Four months of successful operation of a newly organized medical and nurse service in six of the city's academic high schools, the first of its kind provided for from public funds, was reported yesterday by Commissioner of Health Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins. He said there was urgent need to extend this service to other schools.

Pointing up the possibilities in newly created fabrics for manufacturers of women's and misses' daytime dresses, the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers last night displayed to the trade 138 spring styles at its twelfth annual fashion show in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A strike of 750 truck drivers and helpers, which began on Monday after a breakdown in negotiations between-four associations of garment truck operators and members of Local 102, Cloak and Dress Drivers, International Ladies Garment Workers Union, has halted deliveries of finished garments to retail outlets and deliveries of piece goods to manufacturers in the garment center, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin's statement in London yesterday that the British Government would propose referring all refugee problems, including that of the Jews, to the United Nations Organization will not serve to diminish the activities or the hope of accomplishment of the AngloAmerican Committee of Inquiry ...

Jacob S. Potofsky, chairman of the Greater New York Congress of Industrial Organizations Relief Fund and secretary-treasurer of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, issued a statement yesterday calling upon President Truman's War Relief Control ...

A closed conference, lasting two hours, between officials of the General Electric Company and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, continued the stalemate between the groups yesterday after it failed to end in an agreement that would forestall a strike of 200,000 electrical workers scheduled for next Monday. The conference was held at the company's offices at 570 Lexington Avenue.

ALBANY, Jan. 9--Governor Dewey, in his annual message to the Legislature, today raised the possibility of administrative backing for a State bonus to war veterans and outlined a huge spending program which included $1,000,000,000 for public works and liberalized appropriations for housing, aid to municipalities, education and conservation.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 9--Severel controversial issues were raised as the New Jersey Legislature convened today bringing doubt of hoped-for harmony at the 1946 session. Among them was proposed repeal of the pari-mutuel racing amendment to the State Constitution.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 9--In the apple orchard land of Ulster County, a scant two miles south of Kingston, a city of 30,000 persons, the United Nations Organization subcommittee viewed today under leaden skies a possible site for a permanent headquarters for fiftyone nations at Chi-Wan-Da Summer Camp for 200 boys.

One of the largest groups of Army Medical and Dental Corps officers to return from overseas, a total of 276, arrived here yesterday on the transport Aiken Victory, which docked at Pier 84, North River. The ship brought 1,581 service men and women, including seven Wacs and an Army nurse from Le Havre.

TOKYO, Jan. 9--With the revelation that Korea, which normally exported annually to Japan between 36,000,000 and 54,000,000 bushels of rice, this year would almost certainly be able to ship nothing, squabbles among Allied officials over Japan's food supply here have suddenly taken on a graver aspect.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9--Opening a campaign to win public support for the proposed loan of $3,750,000,000 to Great Britain, Secretary Vinson asserted here tonight that there must be an end of economic sword-play in the world and described the loan as sound business which would mean increased production and income for American workers.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 9--Parliament was dissolved today at the request of Premier Achille van Acker, who announced that a general election would take place on Feb. 17. It is assumed on all sides that the brief campaign will be bitter.

With a diminishing volume of business, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose yesterday 5 to 19 points, with distant months relatively stronger than near months. It opened with gains of 6 to 8 points and held steady all day.

People who have been asking "What has become of the Bond Club's luncheon meetings?" got their answer yesterday. Having been compelled, because of insufficient space accommodations, to renounce periodic luncheon gettogethers at the Bankers Club, the members this winter have been a club without a home.

DETROIT, Jan. 9--Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, outlined six "articles of industrial faith" tonight at the annual dinner of the Society of Automotive Engineers. He emphasized that the present need was industrial statesmanship for both labor and management.

James Friskin devoted his elaborate program presented last night at Town Hall to works of Bach. For his purpose the pianist had arranged a list including the Partitas in B flat and D major; the Preludes and Fugues in D major, E major and G major from Book 2, and in G minor from Book 1, of ...

The first meeting of the Assembly of the United Nations today comes exactly twenty-six years after the old League of Nations was formally declared existent and a little over twentyfive years after the first meeting of the League Assembly. The specter at this feast is the failure of the League. On what grounds do we expect UNO to do better?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--Hope for averting a strike in the steel industry was revived today with the announcement that the United States Steel Corporation and the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, would resume their parleys in New York City tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--A prediction that all first class, nonlocal mail will eventually be carried by air at three cents an ounce was made today at a meeting of Postmaster General Robert E. Hannegan and fellow officials with leaders of the air transport industry.

The 30 West Fifty-sixth Corporation sold the five-story store and apartment building at that address to David S. Meister in a deal negotiated by Samuel Kronsky Co., brokers. Occupying a lot 41 by 110 feet, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, the property has fourteeen apartments and is assessed at $135,000.

I am very glad to extend a hearty welcome to the delegates of fifty countries to the General Assembly of the United Nations. It gives me particular pleasure that the first meeting of this great Assembly should be held in London.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) --Mrs. Mary Cicero's Gypster, an excellent weight carrier, hauled 124 pounds and drove to victory by three-quarters of a length in today's featured Manatee Purse as the fancied Stage Bond wound up second at Gulfstream Park.

Edward L. Cushman, assistant administrator of the United States Re-employment and Rehabilitation Administration, warned yesterday that the problem of finding jobs for returning veterans and displaced war workers had assumed "rather alarming" proportions and was increasing because of labor disputes and a reconversion lag in some industries.

With the debut of Joel Berglund as Hans Sachs last night, the Metropolitan Opera became the proud possessor of a first-class Wagnerian baritone. Mr. Berglund is an artist of distinction--a singer who sings with heart and head as well as with the voice and who acts with poise and experience.

The city will begin its new fiscal year on July 1 with a deficit of at least $6,000,000, inherited from the administration of Fiorello H. NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 9--A youth clad in Army garb, armed with an Army-type automatic pistol, held up a teller at 2:35 P.M. today at the United States Trust Company of Newark, 936 Broad Street, diagonally across from City Hall and a short block from Police Headquarters, and escaped on foot with $7,500.

The four-story apartment house at 1524 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, on an irregular plot 60 by 151 feet, has been sold by the Beshar Realty Corporation to an investing client of Goldman Goldman, attorneys. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

LONDON, Jan. 9--British, French and Belgian colonial experts have reached a "fairly complete" agreement to place the three countries' African mandates under the United Nations' trusteeship, it was learned today.

CHUNGKING, Thursday, Jan. 10--Representatives of the Chinese Government and the Yenan Communist regime today ordered an immediate cessation of hostilities on the part of their armed forces.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9--Three days of attending the winter furniture and home furnishings market has not dimmed the optimistic attitude of buyers generally, despite quota restrictions imposed by manufacturers on lines of merchandise and the continuation of indefinite dates for delivery on many orders accepted.

Hope that the Anglo-American credit agreement will actually result in elimination of discriminatory practices which, it is alleged, still prevail against American foreign traders seeking to operate in British markets, was expressed yesterday by foreign traders meeting at the monthly round-table conference of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Under the terms of the agreement, by the end of this ...

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10--Introduction of the first new multiplepurpose steel since the war ended was announced here yesterday by J.L. Perry, president of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, a United States Steel Corporation subsidiary. Known as "Stainless W" because it is an alloy steel, the new product was described as belonging to the working steels and Mr. Perry predicted that it will find broad uses in the nation's industrial machines.
Leaders of industry, retail business and finance joined yesterday in support, of a nation-wide program to prevent-wartime savings from being diverted into fraudulent channels.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP)--A possible major break in the kidnap dismemberment murder of Suzanne Degnan, 6 years old, was hinted today when Detective Sgt. Jack Hanrahan told the Criminal Court that "all of our men" were out looking for another man in the case and "developments depend on our apprehending him."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 9-- Arthur Foster Hebard, former general sales manager of the Remington Arms Company, who had been prominent in various local activities for many years, died here today in his home at the Popham Hall Apartments. His age was 67.

The annual Tobe award "for distinguished service to American retailing" was presented last night to H. Stanley Marcus, executive vice president of the Neiman-Marcus store of Dallas, Tex., in the Hotel Ritz-Carlton.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 9--Although the larger and better-known colleges and universities of this country are turning away qualified veterans, the smaller liberal arts institutions still have room for 250,000 former service men, educators reported to the opening session today of the Association of American Colleges conference.

Early in February what promises to be the most interesting spring training season in the history of organised baseball will be inaugurated at camps in Florida and California. Baseball, emerging from four years of war-time play, moves into the post-war era ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--A sharp contest between the Office of Price Administration and the Department of Agriculture broke out in the open today as price officials told their intentions of carrying to the highest authorities OPA opposition to a proposed in crease in the price of butter. Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, lined up his agency against Secretary Anderson with this statement to reporters:

Frank Stanton was elected president of the Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday at the regular January meeting of the network's board of directors at 485 Madison Avenue. He succeeds William S. Paley, who was named chairman of the board and will continue as senior executive officer.

The plan for a further increase of 18 cents a pound in butter prices by April 1, recommended by the United States Department of Agriculture, was assailed yesterday by the city Department of Markets, housewives, consumer organizations, and a segment of the local butter trade.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--Appearance of the first Navy fighter plane exclusively powered by jet engines, designated as the FD-1 Phantom, was disclosed tonight by the Navy Department.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 9--Four thousand United States soldiers in a mutinous mood, who tried to rush headquarters of the United States Forces in the European Theatre here tonight, with the objective of forcing Gen. Joseph T. McNarney to confront them on their demand to be sent home, were stopped at bayonet point by a small group of guards.

CHUNGKING, Jan. 9--A Government plan to merge China's Army, Navy and Air Force under one unified command was indicated today when the official Central News Agency announced that a single service of supply has been set up for all armed services.
