WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--The Bureau of Reclamation presented a plan for 1946 construction on thirty projects in seventeen Western States estimated to cost $140,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--The Office of Price Administration granted today a price increase of 12 per cent to manufacturers of printing trades machinery and equipment. The adjustment, which goes into effect immediately, is designed to compensate producers for higher factory wage schedules and material costs since 1941, the agency said.
A gift of $350 which the students of Riverdale Country School, Riverdale-on-Hudson, earned for the Hundred Neediest Cases was sent to the fund yesterday by Frank S. Hackett, headmaster.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--A substantial part of the Rumanian population still fears that pro-Soviet forces now in control of the Rumanian Government will rig the forthcoming elections so as to produce a parliamentary majority ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (U.P.)-- Dr. Otto Hahn, Nobel prize-winning German scientist who laid the groundwork for the atom bomb, has been in British custody since he was kidnapped last spring by an Allied combat team in Germany, it was disclosed tonight.

A further gain of 3,289,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline supply in the week ended Jan. 5 has lifted the total to 98,494,000 barrels, the greatest volume for this time of year ever recorded. On the same approximate date in 1940 the store was 84,326,000 barrels; ...

BERLIN Jan. 9--The quadripartite powers have virtually agreed to fix German steel production at approximately 5,800,000 tons yearly and to allow the Germans to maintain steel factories with a capacity of between 7,300,000 and 7,550,000 tons, according to an unimpeachable source.

MANILA, Thursday, Jan. 10-- Master Sgt. James Baldassarre, a survivor of the Bataan "Death March," gave the prosecution a strong hand in putting Lieut. Gen. Masaharu Homma's neck in the noose when he testified yesterday afternoon that he had seen the former Japanese commander passing the infamous San Fernando concentration camp in his automobile.

Sing Sing sentences were imposed yesterday by Judge James G. Wallace in General Sessions on the trio that formed the "hierarchy" of the American Catholic Orthodox Church, Inc., and one of their "lay" collectors for conspiring to defraud numerous business and professional men, mostly in the midtown district, of contributions to charities for the poor.

Silk murals harmoniously combined with hand-fashioned vases and bowls went on exhibition yesterday in the gallery of America House, 485 Madison Avenue. Wall hangings by Lydia BushBrown, a new series of porcelains by Francis Joseph Vontury, and ...

Steel production in 1945 amounted to 79,745,581 net tons, almost 10,000,000 below the high record of 89,641,600 established in 1944, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. Only 2,000,000 tons of the decline occurred in the first half of the year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--It will probably reguire a year to weed incompetent doctors out of Veterans Hospitals, General Omar N. Bradley, Administrator of Veterans Affairs, said at a press conference today at which he and Maj. Gen. Paul R. Hawley, acting director of the new department of medicine and surgery, discussed plans based on recent legislation.

HASTINGS, England, Jan. 9 (U.P.)--Dr. S. Tartakower of Poland won first prize today as the first post-war session of the worldfamous Hastings Chess Congress closed with Tartakower one-half point ahead of his nearest contender, Sweden's brilliant 35-year-old F. Ekstroem.

LONDON, Jan. 9--King George VI welcomed the political leaders of the victorious grand alliance in the state banquet room of St. James's Palace tonight and bade them sublimate selfish national interests to the service of mankind.
Racing's daily double may soon become a thing of the past at New York race tracks, according to the word of Ashley Trimble Cole, chairman of the Racing Commission in this State, last night.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, YOKOHAMA, Japan, Jan. 9--Lieut. Gen. Charles P. Hall, acting commander of the Eighth Army said today that GI demonstrations against the War Department redeployment policy had given "the first indication that a general breakdown in morale and discipline is beginning to show up in the occupation troops." He warned that the enemies of the Allies would be quick to take advantage of the situation. Warns Against Subversion Provost Marshal Comments
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 9 (AP)--Open dealing in financial help to athletes under strict faculty control was proposed by two college presidents today to keep the colossus of post-war sports within bounds.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9--Individuals in the United States salted away another ten billion dollars in liquid savings during the third quarter of last year, raising the total since 1939 to $151,000,000,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 8 (Delayed)--According to the Anatolian Agency, United States Secretary of State James F. Byrnes took to London new proposals for the Dardanelles' and Borporus future, which will be discussed as a topic of the first importance by the United Nations Assembly.

Lehman Brothers and Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., head a group of investment bankers which will today offer for sale 350,000 shares of 3.6 per cent $100 par value preferred stock of the Buffalo Niagara Electric Corporation at $102.85 a share. The underwriters won the award of the stock at competitive bidding at $101.42 a share.

An all-out drive by retailers for more credit customers will be vital in absorbing heavy production of goods later this year as well as to meet increasingly competitive conditions in the retail field, merchants said yesterday at the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The old Horseman from Notre Dame arrived under the cloud and departs in the same manner, neither circumstance doing too much credit to the league.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--Mr. and Mrs. Herrmann B. Tobias of this city, formerly of New York, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Carol, to Lieut. William Bralove Jr., Naval Air Arm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bralove of Washington and Layhill, Md.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--The Department of Agriculture estimated today that the world output of beet and cane sugar for 1945-46 will be 27,800,000 short tons, raw value, or about 400,000 tons less than in 1944-45.

OTTAWA, Jan. 13 (Canadian Press)--The visit to Canada of Field Marshal Montgomery, originally scheduled for April, has been postpond until September, it was announced today by the office of Prime Minister Mackenzie King. The reason for the postponement was not given.

Survivor of more than a score of torrid battles in local rings, Cleo Shans, California lightweight, returns to the metropolitan area at the St. Nicholas Arena tonight, when he tackles Pat Foley, Worcester, Mass., boxer in the main event of ten rounds.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 (AP)--Filmdom's annual task of electing its top artists and technicians began today with the mailing of 9,000 ballots by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
LONDON, Jan. 13--The program for the United Nations General Assembly tomorrow follows:

LONDON, Jan. 13 (U.P)--More than 3,000 persons joined in a Communist party anti-Fascist demonstration and parade at Hyde Park today. The demonstrators distributed literature demanding that the Government render all Fascist propaganda in Britain illegal, and banning the printing of pro-Fascist books or pamphlets.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 13--Postponement last night of the industry-wide steel strike for one week by Philip Murray at the request of President Truman is expected to result in a week of intensive "war of nerves." With another White House meeting called for Wednesday, the steel industry and its consumers will be in a state of suspense, with pressure for deliveries even stronger than ever.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--The State Department plans to offer permanent positions in the career foreign service to 250 of those of outstanding ability who are in the service under temporary war appointments.

A full realization of the "high and holy" nature of marriage as a God-given "vocation," was urged yesterday by the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan, assistant chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, Cardinaldesignate, presided in the sanctuary.

In his debut recital at Town Hall last night, Ralph Sheldon, young American pianist, created for his listeners a picture of a talented and purposeful young artist, though one who still has long strides to make before he can be called an accomplished one.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 13-- Announcement has been made by Mrs. Edwin Thomas Reynolds of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Barbara Rosemary, to Ensign William Parshall Kalb, USNR, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Powell Kalb of Grosse Pointe, Mich.

A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Frank B. Orr of 127 East Seventieth Street Saturday in LeRoy Sanitarium. Mrs. Orr is the former Miss Nancy Gardiner Willard, daughter of LeBaron Willard of Pleasantville, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Annabelle Van Nostrand Willard. The child will be named Nancy Van Nostrand.

The Railroad Employees Corporation has obtained a seven-year term loan of $600,000 from the Marine Midland Trust Company to redeem on Feb. 11 its 5 per cent. convertible sinking fund debentures due on Dec. 1, 1956.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Eiscopal Church, urged immediate renewal of missionary work in China, Japan and India, in a sermon yesterday at Grace Church, Broadway and ...

Joseph W. Frazer, chairman and president of the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation, announced yesterday that the corporation had sold all authorized and outstanding stock of its subsidiary in Warren, Ohio, the Warren City Manufacturing Company, to the Federal ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP)-- The Navy announced plans today to expedite the discharge of personnel near eligibility on points and for whom suitable assignments are not available.
Now the season is approaching when the commuter from the ice-bound suburbs will need to exercise to the ...

TOKYO, Jan. 13--The Japanese Government tonight was ordered by Allied Headquarters to hold the First general election under the new law guaranteeing suffrage to women and young men "not earlier than March 15," and under the safeguards prescribed by the occupation forces.

DETROIT, Jan. 13 (AP)--Two goals by Harry Watson, Detroit left wing, in the last nine minutes of play brought the Red Wings a 3-to-1 National Hockey League triumph tonight over the leagueleading Montreal Canadiens before a crowd of 13,653 fans.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 13(AP)--Haitian troops slowly restored order here today after a wild night in which natives celebrating the ouster of President Elie Lescot looted and burned property.

The New York regional office of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver, 19 West Forty-fourth Street, has appointed a panel of tuberculosis specialists to examine free of charge applicants for admission to the hospital, it was announced yesterday.

A free course in clay modeling and pottery making will be conducted in eight Wednesday evening sessions beginning Wednesday under the sponsorship of the New York Women's Trade Union League, 247 Lexington Avenue, it was announced yesterday. Men and women may register for the classes by telephoning to the league at CAledonia 5-0684.

P. J. Mastrolia spanned the highlights of social dancing in three centuries and illustrated how the new and the old mingle in present-day popularity on the ballroom floor when he presented a program before the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., yesterday at its January meeting in the Hotel Astor.

BERLIN, Jan. 13 (U.P.)--For the first time since the end of hostilities, Berliners tonight heard a public concert of works of Richard Wagner, whose compositions had been played at Nazi rallies and were favored by Adolf Hitler. The concert was held at the State Opera House.

DENVER, Jan. 13 (AP)--Ellsworth Vines, one-time tennis champion and now golf professional at the Denver Country Club, will leave Feb. 1, Sidney L. Brock Jr., club president, said today. Brock said Vines had accepted a position with a Chicago sporting goods company.

Richard F. Maher, City Hall reporter for The Associated Press, was elected yesterday as president of the Inner Circle, an organization of political writers, at a meeting held in the City Council chamber at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP)-- Members of the Military Order of the Purple Heart have decided, after interviewing scores of combat veterans, that deep down in the heart of most of them is a desire to "get away from it all" and raise chickens.

J. P. Morgan Company announced yesterday that, as sinking fund agent, it is notifying holders of Elgin, Joliet and Eastern Railway Company first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due in 1970, that $1,30,000 has been drawn for redemption on March 1 at 105 per cent together with accrued interest, out of funds in the sinking fund.

LONDON, Jan. 13--Enid StampTaylor, well known stage and movie actress, died today in St. George's Emergency Hospital, Wimbledon, where she had undergone two operations for a fracture of the skull suffered in a fall in her Park Lane apartment five days ago. Her age was 41.

A medical art show featuring 125 paintings and drawings by thirty-five medical artists will open today and will continue through Feb. 12 at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street. Sponsored by Modern Medicine, a medical publication, the show is free to the public.

The refusal of the General Electric and Westinghouse Electric Companies to agree to a proposal that the strike set for tomorrow at 5 A.M. be postponed on the basis that both offer a 15-cents-an-hour increase and agree to negotiate the remainder of the $2 a day demanded ...

The National Ski Patrol System, a voluntary organization that has aided more than 7,500 skiers who have needed assistance on slopes and trails since its origin eight years ago, is planning a concerted drive for membership from Feb. 10-24. C. Minot (Minnie) Dole, chairman, revealed yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 13 --Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Cohen of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Marjorie, to Capt. Myron K. Wilson, AUS, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Wilson of Forest Hills, L. I. ...

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 12 (Delayed) --Amid showers of handbills and shouted urgings from loudspeakers, thousands of Koreans in the capital today turned out to participate in a demonstration to end demonstrations against the proposed "trusteeship."

Dormant since the start of the war, the Bulldog Club of America came out of its enforced inactivity yesterday when it conducted a match event at Werdermann's Hall for dogs that have not earned championship points.

BALBOA, C.Z., Jan. 13--Gen. H.H. Arnold, chief of the United States Army Air Forces, objected to the use of the word "defense" in questions at a press conference here today, saying: "I do not like that word." He emphasized the preservation of peace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--Economic objectives of Britain's Labor Government were outlined today by Herbert Morrison, leader of the House of Commons, "as the estimate balancing of production and consumption after revival of export trade and the toleration of only those shortages as are necessary under that program."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Jan. 14--The recommendations of the general board that has been studying the performance of airborne divisions would increase the efficiency of those fighting units by making them heavier, stronger and more versatile by incorporating additional facilities for ground ...

PARIS, Jan. 14--The agreement on the division of reparations from the three western zones of occupation in Germany among eighteen nations and the creation of an inter-Allied reparations agency in Brussels went into force today after its signature at the Foreign Office by Foreign Minister Georges Bidault, Ambassadors Jefferson Caffery of the United States and Alfred Duff Cooper of Britain and the diplomatic envoys of Yugoslavia, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

"I AM of a naturally timorous disposition," writes Capt. George Millar in "Waiting in the Night."* A more extreme example of British self-deprecation than this has rarely been put into print, for Captain Millar is certainly one of the most intrepid soldiers who has yet set down the story of his own adventures.
Preferred stock offerings aggregating $8,060,000 in behalf of two industrial enterprises will be made today by two groups of investment bankers here.

The largest budget in the history of the New York City public school system, calling for an expenditure during the 1946-47 fiscal year of $159,316,056, will be presented to the Board of Education for its consideration at a special meeting on Jan. 22 at the board's headquarters, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--Plans for breaking up on March 2 the great Allied wartime shipping pool of 17,000,000 tons, which delivered armies, food and munitions to all the world's battlefields, will be made at a conference of the sixteen member nations of the United Maritime Authority in London on Feb. 4, it was learned today.

Two hundred and twelve Wacs were among the 3,577 military passengers who arrived here yesterday on the aircraft carrier Enterprise, from Ponta Delgada, in the Azores, where they had been taken aboard the warship after the two transports on which they embarked originally from France had been battered by heavy seas and forced into port.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--The Office of Price Administration placed today price ceilings on thirteen equipment items if any of them were offered when Army and Navy stores hold close-out sales.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 14--Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz, on Adolf Hitler's order soon after the United States had entered the war, directed the German submarine fleet to destroy the crews as well as the ships of the Allies, the prosecution charged today before the International Military Tribunal, which called for an early clarification of the charge of criminality against a half-dozen organizations of Nazi Germany.
The stock market demonstrated again yesterday its sensitivity to the labor-management situation with a sweeping response to the brightened outlook for a solution of the national industrial strife ...

In the fifth day of its meeting at the Hotel Commodore, the National Football League yesterday succeeded in accomplishing nothing, so far as agreement on a 1946 schedule or making its selections in the draft are concerned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--A joint Anglo-American statement tonight set forth seven major policy recommendations affecting the economic development of territorial and colonial possessions in the Caribbean, including plans for expanding production of food crops and livestock to make the islands more nearly self-supporting and to improve the diet of the natives.

Clearing up labor-management discord was viewed as a "formidable undertaking" that Congress should expedite to relieve a situation "becoming rapidly intolerable," according to a survey of business conditions issued yesterday by Brig. Gen. Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company.

Two five-story buildings at the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Ninety-first Street have been sold by the Keefer Pelzer Corporation to the Anadulsia Holding Company. The property, which fronts 100 feet on Lexington Avenue, is assessed at $135,000. Percy Lewis and F.J. Mahoney were the brokers.

An organization to be known as the Friends of Medical Research has been formed to inform the public about animal research and its contribution to public health, it was announced last night at the monthly meeting of the Society of Medical Jurisprudence at New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.
Sidney Foster, a young pianist with a fluent technic and agreeable tone, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. His program embraced Beethoven's E major Sonata, Op. 14, No. 1, the Chopin B ...
The Albeneri Trio, which is made up of Alexander Schneider, violinist; Benar Heifetz, 'cellist, and Erich Itor Kahn, pianist, was heard in recital at Town Hall last ...

Carrying out the theme that spring and summer fashions for 1946 must make the returning veteran forget the olive drab and navy blue uniforms worn in service, fashion designers emphasized light colors, bold patterns and novelty fabrics last night in their first post-war style show for men at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 14-- More than 5,000 members of the United Steel Workers Union, CIO, walked out today at five plants in Massachusetts in the first of several strikes scheduled to involve more than 40,000 employes before the week-end.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 14--A charge that the Argentine Foreign Ministry damaged Argentine and United States interests by not taking effective measures to block funds that the Austrian armaments manufacturer, Fritz Mandl, had invested in a blacklisted Argentine airplane factory, was made today by Naval Capt. William D. McKinley on resigning his post as Government administrator of the company involved.

THE National Football League has been holding meetings for approximately a quarter of a century and it is doubtful if any of them were as momentous as the marathon session which will be completed today. The convention had started out so tamely that some of the newspaper experts complained about the lack of news to George Strickler, the extraordinarily efficient Public Relations counselor of the NFL.

Fears that the Tom Smith doping case would develop into the status of true rivalry for the fictional "Jarndyce vs Jarndyce" of Charles Dickens' "Bleak House" began to subside yesterday when counsel for both sides in the lengthy litigation rested their cases. At the conclusion of the session dealing with the appeal of the veteran trainer from a suspension, both sides were directed to file briefs.

LONDON, Jan. 14--Pedro Lopez of the Philippines today withdrew his request that the United Nations General Assembly recommend the immediate convening of an international conference on the freedom of the press after Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg had promised United States support at a future date--interpreted by Senior Lopez to mean the second part of the General Assembly, tentatively scheduled for May.

A strike of 200,000 electrical workers, called for 5 o'clock this morning, appeared certain last night to halt production of a major part of the nation's radio sets, washing machines, toasters and thousands of other electrical appliances for home and industrial use.

"The City Hall nerve center of the municipal administration is undergoing radical changes under Mayor O'Dwyer's plan to improve administrative efficiency and to delegate administrative responsibility," a communique from the Mayor's office said last night.
The Salvation Army holds, among charitable organizations, a position of high esteem and respect in the hearts of the American people.

Increase in unit production of case goods during the current year of 50 per cent compared with 1945 was predicted yesterday by John Jaffin, representing factories in the Jamestown area, New York, New Jersey and the South.

Hugo Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan, following a tour of parts of Manhattan, announced yesterday that he would be forced to apply to the Board of Estimate from time to time for "substantial sums" to correct faults and mistakes of the preceding administration.
The telephone bell rings and there is no answer. Yet the message to be conveyed may be important.

The difficulties of municipal hospitals operating with acute shortages of nurses and other hospital personnel have been increased by the need to care for well babies in beds critically needed for sick children, Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday. "Well baby wards" have been made necessary because of a lack of foster homes for children whose own homes have been temporarily broken up.

At the annual meeting yesterday of stockholders of the Empire Trust Company Henry C. Brunie, president, announced that net operating earnings for 1945 amounted to $921,378 or $13.16 a share, compared with $756,847 or $10.81 a share for 1944.

ALBANY, Jan. 14--W. Kingsland Macy, Republican chairman of Suffolk County, took his seat tonight as a member of the State Senate and announced that he intended to retain his membership on the Board of Regents, which governs the State educational system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--President Truman proposed Congressional repeal today of $5,751,428,483 in appropriations and $420,079,000 in contract authorizations, but said that the net reduction in authority to obligate would be $5,021,887,483 because $1,149,620,000 would be needed later to liquidate contract authority still on the books.

LONDON, Jan. 14--Britain has failed to obtain major support for her plan to have the General Assembly of the United Nations Organization establish a commission to cope with the refugee problem and was reported tonight to be coming around to a proposal for a specialized agency with limited functions to deal with some phases of the question.

Settlement of the nine-week strike of 4,000 Manhattan and Bronx plumbers was announced yesterday by the Association of Contracting Plumbers of New York and confirmed by the union.

The board of directors of The Associated Press, the largest newsgathering agency in the United States, has directed its executives to cease supplying its news to the State Department for free dissemination abroad, it became known yesterday. After having been postponed several times at the request of the State Department, the decision will be put into effect tomorrow.

The movement of telegrams in and out of New York City was slightly better yesterday than at any time since the strike of 7,000 employes of the Western Union Telegraph Company in this area was called seven days ago, it was said by Ralph H. Kimball, vice president in charge of industrial relations. A "few operators have returned to work," he asserted.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 14 --Premier Petru Groza has taken a positive step toward making the Moscow promises effective by calling a conference tomorrow with three key Ministers to discuss the particular steps for carrying out the promises of restoration of civil liberties, it was announced tonight.

Prompt release by Government agencies of a large amount of unused space that they no longer need for war purposes, and initiation of a share-the-office-or-loft movement in New York offer the best hope of meeting temporarily the immediate pressing demands by veterans for quarters in which ...

Telephone service throughout the United States returned virtually to normal yesterday as pickets were withdrawn from telephone exchanges and the worst communications tie-up in the nation's history came to an end.

Joe Dolan, Spokane featherweight, who boasts nine straight victories since making Brooklyn his home, has been engaged to battle Benny May, Montreal, in the feature eight-round bout tonight at the Park Arena, the Bronx, replacing Georgie Knox who sustained an injury in training. The eight-round semi-final will bring together Julie Bort, Brooklyn lightweight, and Lou Prince, Bronx favorite.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP)-- The prepared text of Secretary James F. Byrnes' address to the United Nations Assembly in London, as released today by the State Department:

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 14, (U.P.) Gov. Raymond E. Baldwin directed the state board of mediation and arbitration tonight to use its "full power and authority" to end the sixty-nine-day strike of 3,500 Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, lock makers at Stamford.
TOKYO, Jan. 14--Legal literary pirating has been ended here.

LONDON, Jan. 14--While the United Nations Organization, officially less than a week old, is struggling through its formative stages, the British Government has proposed to give one of the chief organs of the UNO, the International Court of Justice, its first definite case. Britain has offered to submit to the new world court, whose judges have yet to be appointed, her century-old dispute with Guatemala over the territory known as British Honduras or Belize.

The General Shoe Corporation, in a preliminary statement for the fiscal year ended with last October, disclosed yesterday an increase in net sales to $51,177,678 from the $44,245,055 volume of the preceding fiscal year.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14--Federal mediators worked without success today to avert a meat strike and, with the deadline little more than twenty-four hours away, the prospects of peace seemed dimmer than ever.

The dignity of the New York County Supreme Court almost gave way yesterday under a barrage of paper airplanes when, because of a clerical error, 5-yearold Frederick Fischbach appeared at the Court House to qualify as a Supreme Court juror.

OXFORD, Miss., Jan. 14 (U.P.)-- Harold (Red) Drew, line coach at the University of Alabama, will succeed Harry Mehre as football coach at the University of Mississippi, it was announced tonight. Tad Smith was named new athletic director.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 14--As a result of the unprecedented precautions taken by the police and military to prevent further terrorist attacks on vital installations, Jerusalem is taking on the aspect of a fortified city. The British are digging in for battle and are taking no halfway measures.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 13 (Delayed)--The meeting of the joint American-Soviet Military Commission for Korea will take place at Seoul, it was announced today by Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, commander of the United States forces in Korea.
The beginning of a drive to obtain $905,500 for expansion work of the Young Men's Christian Association, was announced yesterday by Frank M. Totton, president of ...

A representative field of competitors will be on view at the Metropolitan Association A.A.U. track and field meet scheduled for Saturday. The program will be held in two divisions, with afternoon events listed for South Field, Columbia University, and the evening activities scheduled for the Twenty-third Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.
L. Frank Kohler, senior civil engineer and budget officer of the Board of Transportation, died yesterday while eating lunch at the Wool Club, 260 West Broadway. His age was 62.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--The Seventy-ninth Congress reconvened today in a mood which found it abandoning for a day the cry of "Get the boys back home" while members vented their feelings on labor-management strife and strikes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP)--An industry protest that price ceilings for lumber are causing black markets and diverting output from home construction was reported today by the Civilian Production Administration.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 14 (AP)--Grant Thorn's He Got There, a "good thing" that closed favorite at $7.10 for $2, lived up to his name today when he rallied to win the Dixie Purse, feature of the program that ushered in the final three days of the Gulfstream Park meeting.
NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 14--Hjalmar Schacht, it was learned today, is considering offering proof of his own treason against Germany as part of his defense before the International Military Tribunal.

Two 19-year-old youths released recently from prison after serving two years for participating with six others in raping a 17-year-old girl were in custody again yesterday on a similar complaint. Held with them was a 20-year-old exsoldier who won several decorations in the European Theatre of Operations.

The carbonated beverage industry will receive allotments of sugar of at least 80 per cent of 1941 requirements and might possibly get 100 per cent in the fourth quarter of this year, Ody Lamborn of ...

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14--The Securities and Exchange Commission approved conditionally today a second alternative amended plan of reorganization for the Portland Electric Power Company, filed by its independent trustees and providing, among other things, for its dissolution.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14--The American Gas and Electric Company filed today an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission requesting permission to borrow $25,000,000 from six banks.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 14--The great nationwide lockout ordered by Argentine industry and commerce as a protest against the Government's social and economic policies got under way today, and it paralyzed almost all activities throughout the length and breadth of the land. Retailers obeyed the orders of their federation with especial discipline, and hardly a shop was open anywhere in Argentina today.

As part of a drive to produce keener competition among topnotch boxers the National Boxing Association has notified all champions to sign for title bouts not later than April 1, urging the championship matches be held not later than June 1, with a single exception.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--In a decision defining the taxing power of the Federal Government over State activities, the Supreme Court by six to two today rejected the claim of New York State for immunity from United States excise taxes on bottled waters sold from the State reservation at Saratoga Springs.

The first step toward the formation of the new International Court of Justice provided by the Charter of the United Nations has been completed with the nomination of seventy-eight eminent international jurists to its bench.
Convinced he is undertaking "the most important thing that ever happened to the Brooklyn ball club," President Branch Rickey yesterday announced plans for a Feb. 1 start on Dodger training.

CHUNGKING, Jan. 14--Proposals for extensive reorganization of the central government, outlined last week by Dr. Sun Fo, were accepted by all parties as a basis for discussion at the fifth session of the Political Consultation Conference here this afternoon.

KINDLEY FIELD, Bermuda, Jan. 14--This dispatch is being written less than three hours since we left La Guardia Field. Actual flight time to this point was two hours and twenty-two minutes. The Pan American Airways Constellation clipper, on which we made the flight in comfort at 15,000 feet altitude, is returning to La Guardia Field in a few minutes.
LONDON, Jan. 14--The Very Rev. Dr. Joseph Herman Hertz, Chief Rabbi of the United Hebrew congregations of the British Empire since 1913, died in his home here today. His age was 73.

The complete list of National committee chairmen of the Amateur Athletic Union was announced yesterday by President William N. Greim of Denver. Fourteen newcomers and twentyone holdovers make up the slate.

BATANGAS, Philippines, Jan. 14 (AP)--Angry words between a United States Senator and an Army sergeant highlighted a two-hour hearing today by a Senate subcommittee investigating charges that Army surplus disposal troops were burning usable clothing to get rid of it.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 14 (AP)--A thousand United States Army enlisted men met Secretary of War Patterson at the airport today and petitioned an opportunity to discuss demands for a mere clear-cut policy on discharges.

Two more large group annuals have been added to the season's schedule of art exhibitions. At the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue, the annual exhibition of small pictures opened to the public yesterday.

Reaching a new high record in Christmas trade, sales of leading mail order and chain store companies increased 8.8 per cent in December over the like month of 1944, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ALBANY, Jan. 14--Recommendations of the Moore Commission that the State give municipalities more generous financial assistance were submitted tonight to the Legislature with a special message from Governor Dewey urging their enactment into law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--The Pearl Harbor Investigating Committee, in an apparently general mood for expediting its proceedings, which it appeared might result in a decision not to call Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, one of the few remaining major scheduled witnesses, prepared today to resume its inquiry tomorrow.

MANILA, Tuesday, Jan. 15--A succession of Filipino witnesses yesterday afternoon and this morning described Japanese brutalities and unspeakable living conditions, which resulted in the deaths of more than 1,500 American and approximately 29,000 Filipino prisoners of war in Camp O'Donnell. Lieut. Gen. Masaharu Homma, now on trial for his life as a war criminal, was commander of Japanese forces in the Philippines at that time.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14--Highway construction throughout the country is far below the estimates for this time and will not be well under way before midsummer, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, said at the opening session of the annual meeting of the American Road Builders Association here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The Administration will make it plain when steel wage conferences resume Wednesday at the White House that an offer to award to the steel industry a price increase of $4 a ton is contingent on settlement of the wage dispute and the avoidance of a strike, it was reported here today.

BERLIN, Jan. 14--The two most important trends in the American military government--the centralization of German administration and the shift in the burden of denazification to the Germans from the Americans--were discussed in a press conference held today by Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, deputy miiltary governor.

LONDON, Jan. 14--Important private conversations have been started at the United Nations Organization General Assembly meeting on which Pacific islands the United States intends to place under the UNO Trusteeship Council and on how many troops the are prepared to make available to the Security Council.

LONDON, Jan. 14--Secretary of State James F. Byrnes asked the United Nations General Assembly today to adopt the Big Four's atomic energy resolution and proposed that the Security Council start work at once on defining the size of the forces to be placed at the disposal of the new world organization.

PARIS, Jan. 14--A joint United States, Russian and British reply to the French request for explanations of decisions taken by the Big Three Foreign Ministers in Moscow was handed to Foreign Minister Georges Bidault by Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador, this afternoon shortly before the beginning of a five-hour Cabinet meeting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--W. Stuart Symington, Surplus Property Administrator, submitted to Congress today a report embodying a policy for disposing of 350 Government-owned aircraft plants, built during the war at a cost of $3,800,000,000.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 14-- The nation's steel mills lumbered back into production today, but at schedules far below capacity in many instances after slow downs preparatory to the walkout set for today, which was postponed for a week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--Medical and surgical consultants for the Veterans Administration decided today to appoint 250 deputies to help carry out basic policies arranged for veterans hospitals. The deputies will be physicians, surgeons and specialists of the thirteen VA areas.

LONDON, Jan. 14--Kaffirs provided a weak feature in the stock markets today, prices giving way sharply on renewed selling by speculators in London and Johannesburg. Western holdings recorded the largest loss--a quarter --and other issues were up to an eighth lower.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--The Office of Price Administration, in an attempt to check rising cotton prices, issued today formal notice of proposed ceiling prices on the 1946 crop of raw cotton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--The crew of the Yale Victory which sailed six months ago with material to beat the Japanese and is still wandering the Pacific with the ship's original cargo, has cabled its exasperation to THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Samuel J. Eaton of New York City was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

Attorney General William L. Haddon of Connecticut, representing Gov. Raymond E. Baldwin, conferred here yesterday with Dr. Stoyan Gavrilovitch, chairman of the seven-man site-studying committee for the United Nations Organization, and assured him that Connecticut would grant extraterritoriality rights and other privileges to the permanent UNO establishment if it should be located in his State.
A balance sheet of Kaiser-Frazer Corporation as of Nov. 30, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with the proposal to issue 1,800,000 additional shares, which will ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 14--Patents controlling Vitamin D, the socalled "Sunshine Vitamin," which prevents and cures rickets, became public property today when Federal Judge John P. Winston Churchill, Britain's war Prime Minister, arrived here last night on the Queen Elizabeth for a vacation of about nine weeks. He declared that he was not yet ready to retire from politics.

Asking Americans to make good their pledges to the Filipino people, Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, hero of Corregidor, appealed yesterday for contributions to the Victory Clothing Collection. He said serviceable, lightweight clothing and shoes were needed by Filipino children, men and women for "selfrespect and courage."

CHUNGKING, Jan. 16--Incorporation of the reorganized Communist forces into the unified National Army may be completed within the next three months, Gen. Chang Chun, Government spokesman, told the Political Consultation Conference here today.

Two associations of dress manufacturers appealed to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday to intervene in the strike of 750 garment truck drivers, which has already made thousands of workers in the city's largest industry idle and which threatens to force a complete shutdown affecting 100,000 workers if it is not settled by next week.

Elliott V. Bell, New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced here yesterday that he had recommended to the Legislature cuts ranging from about 12 to 20 per cent in the annual interest rates which licensed small loan companies may charge individual borrowers and at the same time proposed that the maximum amount which may be lent to any borrower be raised from $300 to $500.

Operations of Lane Bryant, Inc. and its subsidiaries in the six months ended on Nov. 30, last, resulted in a net profit of $799,561 after depreciation, interest, provision for taxes and all charges, according to the unaudited report issued yesterday.

A major step in the company's plan of expansion during 1946, which embraces a comprehensive organization program with the creation of several new executive positions to strengthen the coast-tocoast operations, was announced yesterday by Croil Hunter, president and general manager of Northwest Airlines.

Robert Garland, Arthur Laurents, Wendell Corey, Shirley Van, Jan Stirling, Gordon Heath and Mme. Jan Paponek will be guests of honor at the Theatre Assembly meeting tomorrow afternoon to be held at the Hotel Astor.

A consumer survey to determine what housewives want on the labels of the foods they buy is now being conducted by Flanley Woodward, a publicity agency, on behalf of one of its clients, the Grocery Manufacturers of America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP)-- General Bradley, Veterans Administrator, ruled today that veterans were not entitled to unemployment compensation under the GI Bill of Rights when they were deprived of work by a strike.

Standard Brands, Inc., manufacturer and distributor of grocery products, is planning to enter the home film sales and processing business on a scale intended to make the organization one of the biggest operators in that field, it was learned yesterday.

Command of the Eastern and Gulf Sea Frontiers, stretching from Maine to the Gulf of Mexico and extending 400 miles into the ocean, and of the Sixteenth Fleet with its inactive reserve of 1,000 combatant ships was taken over yesterday by Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid at a brief ceremony at frontier headquarters, 90 Church Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel asserted today that he did not believe the Japanese would "chance the great hazard" involved in a carrier attack on Hawaii, but added that had he received the intelligence available in Washington, "there never would have been the kind of Pearl Harbor there was."

LANSFORD, Pa., Jan. 16 (AP)-- Waving banners asking "Welcome Home for What?" former service men picketed anthracite mines in eastern Pennsylvania's Panther valley today in what they called a fight for jobs.

LONDON, Jan. 16--Delegates to the United Nations General Assembly are showing great interest and asking a lot of questions about the strikes in the United States and the demands of the American soldiers to go home.

Dr. Allan O. Whipple, Valentine Mott Professor of Surgery in the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, was designated yesterday by the board of managers of Memorial Hospital as the recipient of the annual Judd award for having made "the greatest advancement to the discovery of a cure for cancer."

The name of Wayne Johnson, chairman of Mayor O'Dwyer's campaign committee and adviser to the Mayor, has been put forward as a possible candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, it was learned yesterday, increasing the number of prospective candidates under discussion to at least seven.
TOKYO, Jan. 16 (AP)--The man who held the Emperor's purse strings quit his job today, resigning under the pressure of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's political purge directive.

For the first time in the long history of the banking house of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., it expressed itself yesterday publicly on the general economic outlook for the United States and the world. It was optimistic, with important reservations.

Teachers, maintenance workers and students of the four municipal colleges joined yesterday in attacking as "miserably inadequate" a proposed Board of Higher Education budget of $11,723,885 to operate City, Brooklyn, Hunter and Queens Colleges in the fiscal year 1946-47.
Racing in 1946 should enjoy its most popular year since George Washington and Maryland's colonial Governor Eden raced their horses at Annapolis.

By way of letting the baseball world know that his Dodgers are coming back in this new post-war era with all their oldtime gusto, Branch Rickey yesterday announced a 44-game exhibition schedule for the Flatbush Flock with enough complications attached to test even the distinguished professor himself.

Five defending titleholders and a host of former champions are among the 337 entries received for the senior metropolitan A.A.U. indeed track and field championships Saturday night at the Twenty-third Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, under the sponsorship of the Brooklyn Council, Veterans of Foreign Wars.

Sylvia Marlowe, harpsichordist, gave her first local recital last night in Town Hall. The youthful artist's seriousness of purpose was reflected in her program, consisting of masterworks of Bach, Handel, Haydn and Scarlatti. Loving care was-expended on the interpretations of these classics in performances especially commendable for their imagination and charm.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--An increase of more than a half cent a pound in the price of sugar will go into effect early next month, the Department of Agriculture disclosed today.

BOSTON, Jan. 18--While the seven-man United States sitestudying committee inspected 120 miles of Massachusetts countryside today, the village of Hyde Park, N.Y., occupied its attention for the second successive day.

Yesterday was a day of both pleasure and pain for Lieut. Keith F. DuBois of Green Bay, Wis. He came winging across the Atlantic from Germany to New York for his first glimpse of his 8-month-old son, Allan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--General Eisenhower declared in a radio address tonight that the policymaking, branches of the Government would have to curtail occupation and other functions if the Army failed to get sufficient replacements, for he intended to discharge every eligible soldier by next June 30.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18--The decision of Federal Judge Paul Lehy, permitting the Standard Gas and Electric Company to pay off notes and debentures in cash instead of both cash and a package of portfolio securities, as originally planned, may be appealed to the United States Circuit Court by a group of Pacific Coast owners of such notes and debentures.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18-- "Frozen Gold," a film suggested by the current gold-mining activity in the Yellow Knife Bay district of northern Canada, has been scheduled for production early in the spring by William Pine and William Thomas for Paramount. The cast of the picture, the screen play for which is being written by Maxwell Shane, will be headed by Robert Lowery and Russell Hayden. Thomas will be the director.

It is obvious that the country is thinking furiously on the issues brought into the foreground by the protest meetings of American soldiers overseas. If the amount of mail and comment received by every newspaper and every writer on the subject is an index, no current question stirs the public so much.

LONDON, Jan. 18--Strength of British Government stocks was the outstanding feature in today's stock markets. A large turnover was reported, with most of the buying centering on long-dated stocks. Gains up to 3/8 point were seen.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 19 (AP)-- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today issued an order establishing an international military tribunal for the Far East to try top war crimes suspects, and made public a charter under which the tribunal will work.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18--Despite the dwindling stock of processed meat, due to the strike of the CIO United Packing House Workers, a survey today showed that the Chicago Stock Yards were affected less by the strike of workers in the big packing plants than most other parts of the country.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (AP)-- CIO pickets, who were routed in a battle with police at the United States Motors plant yesterday, marched on the City Hall today with threats to "sweep out of office" Mayor Fletcher Bowron unless he halted "police brutality."
ALBANY, Jan. 18--Increases of capital of several banking institutions featured this week's report of the State Banking Department, issued today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)-- Ivan Bowen, general counsel for the Greyhound Corporation, told a Government fact-finding board today that the company would not be bound by any board recommendations on the bus wage dispute, and that the concern would oppose any effort to examine its books.
Rocky Graziano's knockout string ended last night in Madison Square Garden, but his victory skein continued uninterrupted.

Seven new bond issues offered to the public this week aggregated $9,606,000, compared with eight issues totaling $42,746,000 last week. Offerings for the corresponding week last year amounted to $7,500,000.

In the order of the developments, the market opened lower on the elimination on next Monday of all marginal...

The State Board of Regents in deciding not to make a full-scale investigation of New York City's school system does not issue a blanket approval of conditions in the schools. It specifically recognizes, in fact, a need for improvement of "shortcomings."

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 18--The Mexican Revolutionary party (P.R.M.), the Government-sponsored political organism, today voted its dissolution and promptly announced its reorganization under the new name of Party of Revolutionary Institutions.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 18-- John R. Longo, long a political foe of Mayor Frank Hague, won today his two-year fight against a conviction for fraudulently altering his voting record. Hudson County Common Pleas Judge August Ziegener ordered a new trial on the ground that Mr. Longo had been convicted as a result of "fraud" on the part of the prosecution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The Congressional Pearl Harbor Investigating Committee rejected by a vote of 6 to 2 today Republican demands that Winston Churchill be asked to appear as a witness, and went on to hear Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel denounce as "misrepresentations and lies" rumors that his appointment by President Roosevelt to command the Pacific Fleet was political in motive.
Net income of the American Distilling Company for the fiscal year ended with last September amounted to $868,995 after all charges, including $2,775,000 taxes, the report announced yesterday.

Principals in the electrical workers and Western Electric Company strikes marked time here yesterday as attention in the nation's labor situation focused on the steel parleys in Washington. Flowever, Charles E. Wilson, president of General Electric, once more reiterated that whatever happened in steel wage negotiations would not be reflected necessarily in the position of his company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Failure of the Senate Appropriations Committee, headed by Senator Kenneth McKellar of Tennessee, to approve a routine transfer of funds of the Patent Office has kept from 200 to 300 employes of the agency, scheduled to return from Richmond, Va., to the capital, literally sitting on package boxes for the past week.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 18 (AP)--Fearful of lagging in international airlines competition, Britain was said today to be considering the purchase of American longrange transport planes for transatlantic use until her own new types are ready to fly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--President Truman named Edwin W. Pauley today to be Under Secretary of the Navy and put him in line to succeed James V. Forrestal as civilian head of that establishment on the latter's expected early retirement.

Operations of the Erie Railroad last year resulted in an indicated net income of $5,797,185 after all charges, equal to $1.54 a common share, R.E. Woodruff, president, announced yesterday following a directors' meeting. The net income for 1944 was $7,660,157, or $2.30 a common share.

Leslie MacMitchell's first title bid since his return to competition and a torrid battle for team honors between strong squads representing the New York Athletic Club and New York University are the prospective features of the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior track and field championships at the Twenty-third Regiment Armory, Bedford and Atlantic Avenues, Brooklyn, tonight.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 18. (AP)--An American prosecutor today reported the arrest of the seventh and final important Japanese suspect in the execution of three Doolittle fliers and asserted that the evidence was so conclusive that their trial might require less than a week.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18-- Capt. Gregory Cullen, a veteran ship master of the American President Lines, died at the Marine Hospital here last night in his sev entieth year.

Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, will open a celebration of the 125th anniversary of the founding of the congregation tomorrow that will continue until April 1.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan 18(AP)--With crowd of 17,875 and pari-mutuel pay of $1,009,509 that would have one credit to a Saturday program for pre-boom days, the Hialeah Park meeting that opened yester day in record-breaking fashion continued at a busy tempo today.

ALBANY, Jan. 18--The State Board of Regents referred to its Committee on Higher Education today the request by the State Dental Society for a review of the circumstances surrounding the merger of Columbia University's College of Dental and Oral Surgery and its College of Physicians and Surgeons.

Sonja Henie will introduce the current edition of her Hollywood Ice Revue at Madison Square Garden tonight. The former Olympic ice-skating champion will appear in seven selections on each of the fifteen nights that her show will be in town.

CHESHIRE, Conn., Jan. 18-- Seventeen persons, the entire passenger list of fourteen and the crew of three, were killed near here about noon today when a Miami-to-Boston transport of the Eastern Air Lines crashed in a small ravine and burned. The plane had left La Guardia Field at 10:28 A.M. and was due in Boston at 12:15 P.M.

Criminal prosecution instead of civil action was threatened yesterday by law enforcement officials against butchers who sell meat above ceiling prices as black market sales spread to most butcher shops in many sections of the metropolitan area in consequence of the strike that for three days has kept local plants and branches of the larger packing companies shut.
The Revised Standard Version of the New Testament, on which eminent Bible scholars of North America have been laboring for the last sixteen years, will be issued on Feb. 11.

German food rations should not be increased until the food level of the rest of Europe is raised to that of Germany, the American Committee for Yugoslav Relief has told President Truman in a letter, the committee announced yesterday. CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP)--The Standard Oil Company of Indiana announced today that it had accepted a United States conciliation service arbitration award for an 18 per cent increase in oil workers' wages and would make it the basis for adjustments not only to the employes at the Whiting refinery but to many others.

Into all the gloom over the scarcity of upland game, the Forest Service, United States Department of Agriculture, injects a note of optimism with a report that the nation's big game population, at least, is thriving.

Learning that extension of the Price Control Act beyond June 30 will be one of the first measures to be considered by Congress in its current session, spokesmen for the textile industry yesterday indicated that the move will have substantial backing from fabric and knit goods manufacturers and finishers, provided certain longsought modifications are included.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--President Truman, announcing rejection by the steel industry of his 18.5 cents an hour wage increase proposal, urged again today that his suggestion be adopted by the employers.

Four investment houses were listed yesterday in the weekly bulletin of the New York Stock Exchange as proposed new member firms of the Exchange. Eleven persons have been proposed for admission to member firms and two retirements were announced.

Andrew Jackson won the team title in the Public Schools Athletic League indoor swimming championships, held last night in the Columbia University pool. PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 18-- Endorsement of the cooperative aim of book publishers of the United States to open a distribution campaign for their output in Latin America and in post-war Europe was expressed tonight by Spruille Braden, Assistant Secretary of State, at a dinner in the Princeton Inn, closing a two-day convention of the United States International Book Association.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 3 (AP)--Bob Fitzgerald's speed in the dashes stood him in good stead today to give the Minneapolis star the men's national senior speed skating championship. He dethroned a fellow townsman, Ken Bartholomew.

HOMESTEAD, Pa., Feb. 3-- Carefully instructed by union officials, pickets at gates of the Homestead works of the Carnegie Illinois Steel Corporation opened their lines today to any wanting to enter, carrying out to the letter the terms of an injunction for a close-order picketing.
